There are also a number of wonderful houseboats on the canal.Most boat tours will take you along all or some of Prinsengracht, but a stroll in the early evening or morning is pleasant too. If you are an architecture or history buff this should definitely be on your list of places to see in Amsterdam.

Beautiful place. This place is one of the most beautiful places in Amsterdam. It is not usually very crowded, so it's nice to walk around and chill out. I also enjoyed the views. All the typical Holand houses and all the trees make this place special. It is very near to the centre, so it is perfect to come to this place. This is where you will find the true Amsterdam. There are no such places in other cities. That's why you have to come to this place, walk around and forget that you are travelling and enjoy.
Peaceful Tree-lined Canal. We took a lovely canal trip along the canal and walked it a couple of times enjoying the quiet away from the busy through streets. Pleasant restaurants and bars abound

Grab your camera. One of the main canals that helped me identify where I was in the city all times. If you follow this canal you can easily get to Anne Frank's house and the central station. Grab your camera, snap photos and enjoy the beautiful scenery at leisure.

Canals are the most interesting aspect of the old city. The tour buses cannot get into the old city due to narrow roads so you'll need to walk around. (I would not recommend renting a bike ... too much traffic, aggressive local cyclists, too many pedestrians).Instead, get a tour map and follow several of the canals, especially those marked on the map as having the most attractions to see. And definitely take a canal cruise because that's an excellent way to see the old city.

lovely for a stroll. those boats cruise up and down all day - family groups, people playing loud music, people sharing drinks, people enjoying the sunshine. The passing parade is fun. The shops along the canal are also worth checking out - boutique shops and eateries. A lovely place for a stroll!

Don't miss out on Amsterdam's canals!. f you're in Amsterdam, make sure you take a canal boat trip down the network of beautiful canals...the perfect way to see the city with tranquility! Taking a stroll will offer up Amsterdam's many coffee shops, boutique's & creperies! Do not miss out!

Amsterdam Canals. Amsterdam is an amazing place. The network of canals is facinating and at first were a little confusing until we got our bearings. Although they are all beautiful and have their own individual unique style they all look the same when you are lost looking for your hotel. Take care and you will get your bearings after an hour or so. Fantastic place to visit however be w
beauty on the canal. this was the best canal with the best architecture. lots of things to see and do, 5 star hotels and eateries
Amsterdam experienced. My travel experienced in Amsterdam was so amazing !!! This is the most beautiful city in my life that i have been.

Princely Precinct. This district exudes quality. In the dappled spring sunshine it's a beautiful area to strut, observe, to take a coffee, to enjoy a quiet meal. Its a locale that puts you at ease, makes you feel comfortable and at peace with the world.

Photographer's Dream. This is a really nice canal in Amsterdam. So many more cafes and vintage shops than the others. It is also one of the most beautiful canals to walk down and take photos. All of my favourite photographs of Amsterdam have been taken at this canal. Lovely for a stroll or to use as a thoroughfare to somewhere else!
Well Worth It. Take the canal boat along this scenic route, very enjoyable trip.Would recommend for families and couples.

Great streets of the world. Among the greatest urban settings. The model for how to live in the modern world. Human scale, mixed use neighborhoods. Access to almost everything. Illustrates the power of beauty in life.

So lovely. Beautiful. The canal makes for a great stroll, taking in the best of Amsterdam's sights. Leaning-house spotting was quite fun and it was idyllic to sit on the banks and watch the bobbing houseboats, but, as applies to everywhere else in Amsterdam, beware the bikes - especially in the narrower lanes!
Picturesque canal. The Prinsegracht canal is just around the corner from the hotel we always stay at in Amsterdam. It's a picturesque canal. It's peaceful and relaxing to have a Heineken and sit.
A lovely stroll. A beautiful area for a stroll. Feels safe. This is my favorite part of Amsterdam. Plenty of little restaurants in the area if you want to stop for a bite.

Perfect location in amsterdam. We stayed in the mercure here and I would never stay in any other location now. It is beautiful. Great bagel shops, coffee shops and easy to walk or tram anywhere. It is quiet, clean and feels safe, you have the beautiful architecture everywhere and I could look at the houses and boats all day long.

Strolling Along. We stayed in the beautiful Waldorf Astoria and had a fantastic view out our large windows onto this beautiful canal. Walking along the canal almost made you feel like a local even with map in hand. Imagining living there was part of the experience.

400 years and counting!. go in the Rijksmuseum and see a 1600 painting, then walk outside and it looks the same! -(only now there are cars and trams)...this city is a museum! there are ordinances regarding what color owners can paint their houses to keep the old look intact...it is a walk in history. notice the dates on the buildings, houses were taxed by how wide they are thus the tall ceilings and high gradation stairwells. pulleys attached at the top used to load furniture into the building...some of the bricks are leaning so very far over, all set in sand! yes remember you are below sea level! Prinsengracht is part of the inner canal circle, just lovely.
Lovely stroll along the canal. Had a great Sunday afternoon strolling along the canal, popping into the cheese museum, soaking up the relaxed atmosphere. Plenty of bars, cafes, and shops!
Lovely Section of town. Beautiful canals. Safe and quaint to walk around. Many little shops to explore.. Close to museums . Friendly people. Watch out for people on bikes!

Slice of Amsterdam charmed life. In the morning I sat out in front of the hotel with coffee and croissant and enjoyed the people and bikes, in the twilight I sat at a sidewalk café and watched the people and boats with my dinner.
Stunningly beautiful. Liked everything. Disliked nothing. Loved all the restaurants & cheese shops. Also the canals are dreamy
The most delightful part of Amstedam. We have been lucky enough to be staying in this area and it is just gorgeous, lovely shops, cute cafes and quirky Amsterdam architecture.
Lovely place for a walk by the canals. This is an excellent canal to walk along and see the beautiful old homes and sidewalk cafes. Sunday morning is the best time as it's not so busy.
Awesome. Go On Kings Day April 27th the whole town and all the canals are orange from all of Nederland wearing orange.
Canal tour. We were lucky that we were there when they had their Light Festival. Very pretty. Amsterdam is a lovely place and we just loved their old buildings.

Something for everyone. Typical Amsterdam scenic area - beautiful place to walk, eat, shop and people-watch. Easy walking distance from central station and other tourist destinations. Add it to your 'Saved' list!

Perfectly Positioned. We feel Prinsengracht is perfectly positioned, it's not too central and not too far out.
When visiting Amsterdam this is our favourite place to stay.
Also lovely for a stroll.
Attractive canal.. If you get up very early and go walking the water in the canal is very still great for photos with reflections, plenty of bars etc.
Strolling past canal-side splendour. Quiet, so the guide-book said, but lots of walkers. Very pretty houses, flowers, trees, boats. One of the nicest canal walks

Pretty Area. Pretty area to walk around, see the typical Dutch houses, shop, dine, and see the houseboats. You will walk past the Anne Frank House, as well. This canal walk should not be missed. Take the time to even walk a short distance.

House Boat Haven. We stayed a week on a house boat on the Prinsengracht... and enjoyed every minute of it. There is a little bit of every thing on the canal... Anne Frank House, two churches, a market, shops and many bars and restaurants. Plus... it's very scenic, especially at night... with the street lights and house lights reflecting off the water.

Nice for shopping and people watching. This area contains restaurants, shops, stores, and a lovely canal with boats and lovers strolling along holding hands. It is a nice place to spend a Saturday or Sunday afternoon.

Picturesque. Quiet and peaceful area. Beautiful canals, lovely and dainty old buildings. Great cafes and wonderful to walk around here. Go to the Nine Streets for awesome and local shopping! You will enjoy taking photos around here.
Beautiful. The Prinsengracht is great for strolling around and getting a feel for Amsterdam. It is a beautiful canal lined with typical Dutch houses and easily accessible with several tram lines.
Beautiful area. Spent the day wandering around the area, soaking up the atmosphere. Fab area with lots of cafes to sit and watch the world go by

A scenic walk. Beautiful canals, good shopping and some great eateries. Its a must visit for a nice stroll. You can also see the buildings through the canal tour but this street deserves an hour long walk on its own,

Lovely area. This is the second visit for my wife and I to Amsterdam. We have visited many of the city's neighborhoods and decided to stay in the Prinsengracht this visit. The canals are beautiful, traffic is mostly pedestrians and bicyclists so noise is not an issue. It is close to the Central Station, shopping area of Nieuwendijk, and 10 minute walk to Dam Square or the Red Light District. Plenty of restaurants in the area or a 10 minute walk to the Jourdaan, Anne Frak Huis, Canal tours. Tram stops are within 5 minutes walk too.

The most picturesque canal in Amsterdam. The Prinsengracht is a canal that flows around Amsterdam and is the one most found in pictures. It is located on the edge of the Jordaan District and also the canal in front of the Anne Frank House. When you visit, be sure to bring your camera to capture all the beauty!!!

An antidote to the red light district!. Utterly charming. On a sunny day I can think of no nicer place to be. No tourist tat here, just beautiful buildings with picturesque canals and little coffee shops and cafes. It is less of a tourist magnet than the areas close to Dam Square but it is well worth the short walk. I preferred this area to the more seedy red light district. Take your camera, you won't be disappointed!
Contemporary. I love the nine streets area (Jordan) where you can enjoy premium shopping and a beer in a small caffe on the canal
One of the most picturesque canals. We stayed at the Hotel Pultizer. Do take their canal boat, it is one of the Original boats from circa 1910s. The only way to see Amsterdam!
so much to see. you can walk for miles, sit and watch the world go by, eat and drink in one of the many pubs or cafes or cruise the canals.....wonderful!
It’s all here. Everything we have really enjoyed has been either on or near Prinsengracht. Restaurants, scenes, people, Dam Square is right near there; Anne Frank museum, pancakes!
lovely street amazing history. The lovely houses small roads little shops and Anna Frank house , the canals. We stayed on that street so it was central.
A great canal to walk on. We walked the Prinsengracht from our hotel in the Leidseplein to the Anne Frank House. It is a nice walk with some quaint restaurants and some interesting house boats.

Nice place to walk. The reason this is a 5 star place is because it is easily accessible and provides very nice views. You can walk or ride to this area very easily, and just enjoy the atmosphere, the canal and the many little shops around it.
Nice view!. Spend some time there and relax...if u want u can even take the boat through the canal to see Amsterdam in a different way!

houseboats!. I rented a houseboat on the Prinsengracht and also took a canal tour boat leaving from there. Very charming area with good food and drink around. Try to visit the colorful farmers market Saturday and the Lapjesmarkt ("Fabric market" tho it's also a flea market with some food and produce) on Monday. When you visit Amsterdam, this is a lovely area to visit and to shop.
go for a walk. Just a lovely walk. Take your time, enjoy the walk, this is Amsterdam!Beware of Bikes, and nevermind the crowded surroundings!

Canal street on edge of Jordaan. Plenty of shops and cafes to choose from. Canal-side - plenty going on but not too noisy. It has the Anne Frank Museum and a canal boat stop just outside. The canal is crossed in several places by trams which take you into and out of town. Prinsengracht has a cheese museum, Ellis Gourmet Burgers and a great Bagel shop.

Sums up Amsterdam. As you will see all over Amsterdam that you are never far a way from a canal but they are beautiful and sum up amsterdam in one picture with bikes all chained to the canal railings and boats sailing down the canal with shops and bars along each side of the canal it really is a beautiful city.
Anne Frank Haus. A must but try to pre book online as you are looking at least an hour and half queue everyday no matter what time of day
Riijks Museum. Do not schedule any other event the day you go to the Riijks. There is way to much to see and is a very busy venue. An amazing place.

Favourite Canal. There are a number of canals to vie for Amsterdams best but for us staying in a hotel on this canal and being within easy reach of everything in the city is a must. This time it was experiencing it during the month of May.
One of my favorite canals. We really enjoyed walking along this canal. Very nice area with several bars and restaurants to visit along the way. Highly recommended
Famous Canal. All the canals are great to bike around. This is one of the most famous ones, very charming. Worth the visit and pictures!
Beautiful. Stroll along the canal, stop for a coffee or a beer and stroll some more. Shops, bars and cafés - a beautiful part of the city.
The pancake bakery. Facing the Anne Frank house, on your left past the canal on the next block. A real treat. Don't miss it if you are in the area.

One of my favorite canals. It's one of the longest canals out of the other two - Herengracht and Keizersgracht (if I got the spellings right). Definitely worth a visit. We took a local tour boat along the banks and to our delight, our tour guide turned out to be quite a funny and knowledgeable one briefing us about the history of the place and the "must visits". There are quite a few cafes, restaurants, shops around this lively area. If you walk around Prinsengracht you will come across some of the key tourist attractions like Anne Frank House, Van Gogh Museum, etc. However we couldn't visit any of the museum as we didn't prebook the tickets. If you want to visit these museums, it is advisable to book the tickets in advance. Overall, this place is definitely worth a visit.

Canal!. It is a canal in a city of canals, but they are all rather splendid! This is my first ever review of a canal but what can I say? It rocks. The joy of Amsterdam is the ability to just wander up and down, stroll across a bridge, wander a bit more, call into a coffee shop, do a bit of shopping and carry on wandering. This is the outer canal and full of interesting sights. You can also take a boat trip which takes you along here. Beautiful.
Beautiful area. Stunnign area with loads of resturants/bistros/bars, etc. Can aget quite busy at there peak times and watch out for the bikes!

Leather shop on Prisengracht. The Guild of Holland Atelier leather shop is located close to the Anne Frank House on the Prisengracht. Beautiful leather goods. Handbags, duffel bags, totes, portfolios and much more. Both husband and wife were very courtesy.Note: The store offers VAT refunds, but you should try to settle that before leaving from Schiphol Airport. I wasn't able to receive a refund because Italian Customs were not familiar with the forms I was given at the shop.
peaceful. I love this area of Amsterdam for biking around the city. Not as busy as the other gracht and the longest.

Long and good. The longest of the 4 canals (as it forms the outside of the semi-circle), the Prinsengracht shows a few different scenes, stretching all the way from the north of Central Station to the area near the Zoo. It is part of the UNESCO World Heritage area, and it is easy to see why...And in August, Amsterdam Pride runs their parade on this canal - with real floats! Definitely worth a visit.

Outer Canal. Once upon a time, strolling along the Prinsen would have meant you were lower class, a worker. Not so any more; the canal is very obviously enjoying a renaissance, and is packed with cafes and bars, restaurants and hotels.
So beautiful . I stayed really near this canal, and it is so perfect - it made me fall so much in love with Amsterdam.

Charming to walk about. Interesting architecture around Prinsengracht/Keizergracht/Herengracht and Singel area but you will need to look carefully at the detailing. It would be handy to have a guide book on hand that correlates the detail to a piece of history or story.

Worth the visit. This section has so much to offer, many little shops and markets and so well maintained. The Dutch houses and house boats are wonderful. We learnt that as there is a shortage of available housing many people are taking to living on the canals, and what a huge variety of boats! Definitely a visit not to be missed.
Beautiful. So lovely to walk along this lovely canal. So quiet and peaceful. Interesting to see how people live on and beside the canal. Great corner cafes and shops dotted nearby.

A Kings Day Must See. This section along the nine street and the Jordaan is wonderful anytime. It is replete with stores, markets ( Noordmarkt on Saturdays) and beautiful architecture.
On Kings Day (April 27) it is THE place to be to enjoy the festivities. The boats, the singing and the fun are unique to this country and this city on that day.
Worth the ride through Prinsengracht. This canal has wonderful Dutch Houses made in 17th Century, well maintained.You can walk along the canal as well.

Seems to lead to everywhere..... Our hotel was right on this canal - we took a canal cruise one day and it really is very beautiful - we also learnt quite a lot from our cruise captain. It does seem to get you to many visitor attractions and is lovely to walk along. This is, apparently, the widest of Amsterdam's many canals.
Lovely canal for a walk or a boat ride. One of the most beautiful canals in Amsterdam, great for a lovely walk or a boat ride. Very nice buildings, plenty of bars and restaurants.
good starting point for a boat trip. pleasant area and a good place to start a boat trip. walking around this area is also worthwhile and leads into the 9 streets area of boutique shops and cafe's.
another nice canal in Amsterdam. don't go there without visiting the van Loon museum, very intersting inside this old rich house, well explained.

One of the most beautiful canals (and the widest) in Amsterdam. Beautiful! Take a canal boat (at least to start) to give you and overview of the Keizersgracht (or Emperor's Canal). It's fascinating, with iconic sights. If you possibly can, walk it on foot. (There are lots of connections to it (and to some of the most interesting/iconic sightseeing spots in Amsterdam, as well) via Canal Bus Purple Line which has a stop it). On the canal you will find some stunning architecture. plus the "hidden" Catholic Church, the curious "House with Heads", the "John Adams' House" and museums and cafes galore. Check out all the houseboats!

My favourite canal in Amsterdam. We Walked this canal all the way from one end to the other end and just loved it.Buildings are attractive and hotel we stayed at is here.westerkerk with view from tower is worth to do.beautiful view over Amsterdam

A dream come true. Finally I can say that I visited the lovely Amsterdam Prinsengracht canal.There you will find Anne Franck's House and many lovey shops: curiosa, antics, leather (Guild of Holland), etc.! Cafés are everywhere. Dutch have very good taste in matters of decor ;)

Lovely canal. This is a lovely canal with some nieces cafes and restaurants, especially around the Joordan area. It is good to walk around but also good if you go by boat as you see it form a different perspective.

Canal Life at its Best. Beautiful area for strolling around. The background of traditional architectural gems certainly enhanced the pleasant canal and houseboats. Plenty of cafes to satisfy any hunger and thirst, whilst watching the world go by.

Maybe the most interesting canal. As far as I could tell, the houses got smaller and smaller for each canal I crossed leaving this one as one of the better canals to explore. The end parts of the canal and the canal crossings are the best parts where the houses looks especially crooked.
best canal walk. good area for walking. Many antique stores and small restaurants. typical canal houses from the Amstal River to the Joordan area.
Beautiful canal. One of Amsterdam's most famous canals. Picturesque, neat traditional architecture, a photographer's dream.
great walking area and city. we enjoyed sitting outside with our fresh mint tea! we loved the people watching, shopping, bicycle and boat houses along the canal. life moves slower here!

walking or by boat, a wonderful canal. Amsterdam has so much character with its canal. You can follow them walking or riding a bicycle, or take a tour by boat from close to the Central Station. This specific canal passes in front of the Anne Franck house. You see a lot of great house and offices on the way.
Vibrant area with plenty to see and do. All of the canals in Amsterdam are lined with row buildings but this area includes lots of shops and restaurants...

A classic part of Amsterdam. The canals are what makes Amsterdam special although it is sometimes difficult to walk around the city without being mown down by cyclists or having to stumble round bikes that are just left right across the pavement.

My favourite canal!. Walking along the Prinsengracht will lead you to most "must-see" sights in Amsterdam: Anne Frank Huis, Rijksmuseum, Van Gogh Museum (buy tickets in advance online for all museums!). It's also a handy way to reach Rembrandthuis and Hermitage.
My favourite canal. Lots of shops and cafés and shops.

Anne Frank House. Lovely street to start with, beautiful canal and lots of little cafes. Anne Frank house excellent value at 9 euros. Queued for hour and a half so prebook if possible, but it is worth the wait.

The real Amsterdam. This beautiful canal is bordered by charming canal houses with their beautiful Dutch roof lines and facades, along with unique houseboats floating in front of them on the water. The canal boat ride was really enjoyable!

Soak in the charm of Amsterdam. Prinsengracht is the longest of the main canals of Amsterdam. The notable houses along this canal include Anne Frank House and Noorderkerk. Lovely to walk along the canal or take a boat ride and leisurely soak in the charm of Amsterdam.
Beautiful. A beautiful canal to walk up and down. Restaurants, cafés and coffeeshops. Careful to respect and watch for the bikes :)

Beautiful. This canal is so beautiful. From here you see a lot of new and old house boats with the windows open. People in amsterdam don't close their windows so it's nice to see the inside of these houses.
lovely. Prinsengracht is a lovely canal to walk along, lots of different shops in the nine streets and resturants.

Great Canal with multiple attractions. From all sorts of great eateries, bars, Ann Frank Huis, canal boat stops, cycle Rental, a number of museums and just a fantastic atmosphere.
Prinsengracht has got it in spades. Walk up one side, walk back down the other and then take a boat trip - Amsterdam highlights, all in one place.
Nice place. Nice place to take a walk. Beautiful shops around. Other attractions are really close. Can seat beside the canal and enjoy the beauty.

lovely canal. It was nice sitting here by the canal watching people. There is Cheese Museum and Tulip Museum and Anne Frank Museum close by. It's nice on a sunny day. Walking a long the canal was also lovely.
What a beautiful walk. It's an amazing walk down the graght - lovely houses to view (worth looking up the various house descriptions available online). Watch out for the cyclist lanes!

Great area and fantastic atmosphere. We enjoyed walking up and down the canal and was very excited about the atmosphere and all the old traditional houses. We stayed at a houseboat in the canal and can really recommend it.

A most relaxing Amsterdam weekend. We rented a beautiful flat on the canal at this location for our May bank holiday trip to Amsterdam. The neighbourhood was so relaxing and comfortable. We walked pretty much everywhere and enjoyed every minute. This area will certainly be our first choice on our next visit to this beautiful city.

What a walk!!. I have walked PrincessGracht so many times. Never disappointed. The queues in front of Anne Frank house, the beautiful canal, the small shops, the boutique hotels, cycles and cars...all add to the charm. You can spend a whole day just walking here!!
Outermost and the Longest of the 3 main Canals!. The Prince's canal was named after William I, the Prince of Orange. Do spend some time looking around and strolling along the canal banks
A canal walk. Nice clean safe area with lots of good quality shops and restaurants. A reminder of what old Amsterdam must have looked like.

It's a canal-lots of them here. Not sure why this canal is singled our-didn't seem appreciably different t all the other major waterways in Amsterdam.
The entire city is a gem-get out and walk here and everywhere else!

lovely to walk, look at beautiful buildings. one of the best in amsterdam, spacious with lovely views on buildings and other canals .also a number of nice cafes and restaurants, and very attractive at night. if weather allows not to be missed
Nice place to walk about. Nice place to walk about lots of little restaurants to discover. Markets on the weekend. It's one the wealthiest in Amsterdam.

Beautiful (would be better later on in year!). We went in March and it was a little cold at times, so the only improvement would have been warmer weather and leaves on the trees !Otherwise it was lovely, and nice area to wander in.Lovely architecture and good views of canals and especially at night when the bridges are all lit up, although that might have been another canal, there are so many and they are all nice.

Beautiful. Can't remember all the canal pictures that I took, but any canal picture is worth a visit to see. The views are incredible and it's just like the ones you see in travel books, and postcards. Tried to get a dusk picture, but could never stumble back to the same place.

Impressive and typical Amsterdam canal. To walk along this canal is so relaxing and well worth the trip. It is my favorite of the canals due to the architecture. In my opinion, it is indicative of the typical inner city Amsterdam scene and feel. One can spend hours simply strolling along.

One of Amsterdam's finest canals. Our hotel overlooked this canal and our daily walks gave us the opportunity to see a lot of it. Make the effort to walk at least a kilometer of this one to experience the beauty of this city. A canal boat tour is also highly recommended
Classic. Take a walk or cycle along the Prinsengracht! Shops, cafés and bars are all along and it is absolutely neat to sit down and just watch the boats pass by.

Houseboat heaven. Stayed in a houseboat on this quiet canal for a couple of days, and I wish I was still there! This canal is the Eastern border of the Jordaan area, and the Western border of The Nine Streets, you'll find lots of unique little shops here. It's a rather special place :-)

The canal which is crowned by my all time favourite symbol of Amsterdam. I came for a three month stay in Amsterdam some decades ago with my band from India and happened to live close by the Prinsengracht. Prinsengracht is the furthest of the four main canals (from Central Station) and has two main attractions on it - the Westertoren and Anne Frank House right next to it. The Westertoren symbolises Amsterdam for me. When I stayed close to it the first time, the church bells would enchant me. The swans sliding by and surrounding fairy tale Jordaan area would really thrill me. So much so that I had a dream of one day coming to live in Amsterdam one day.This dream actualy materialised. I live in this charming city for the last fourteen years. I discovered very soon after coming to live here that on Tuesdays, a boat comes by and circles around, close to the Westertoren. The carillion player plays rock and pop tunes on Tuesday afternoons! Around 12 noon a boat comes by - there is a musician in it who plays the organ and the trumpt and does duets with the carillion player in the tower. Spectators are wonderstruck at this experience.

Rent a Canal Bike!. Such a beautiful area! We rented Canal Bikes (near to the Anne Frank house) and it was a fantastic way to explore! Quite stressful with the rules (give way to every other boat, stay on the right, etc.) but so much fun and one of the best parts of our trip!

Living a life. My house faces this amazing canal.
Kings day or Concert Day or Gay Parade are highlights
But just a simple walk is great enough
Perfect place for beer, brunch, coffee and everything you wanted to do in Amsterdam
Lot of memories and of course great pictures
:)
Great shopping. This place is a great shopping area and somehow you end up seeing it multiple times. We must have walked past the area about 4 times in our three day visit.
Beautiful. One of the nicest places in Amsterdam. Beautiful canal with old Amsterdam style houses bordering. Nearby lovely quaint shops nearby to browse.
Great place to do shopping. A perfect place to stroll around, having a small beer or coffee between the small, and interesting shops. Calming atmosphere in the heart of Amsterdam.

Amsterdam at it's finest. One of Amsterdam's most beautiful bodies of water. A walk along one of the canals in Amsterdam during the day and at night is a must for anyone wishing to experience Amsterdam at it's finest.
Enjoy!!. Stroll this canal and enjoy it's architecture ,history and atmosphere,whether it is in daylight or night time when the lights appear on bridges and along the streets.
Beautiful Walk. We walked this canal many many times and always saw different things. An absolute must for a stroll.

Beautiful at night. Take a stroll along this lovely canal,night time it is superb,nice bar's,cafe's and restaurant's in this area to pop in and have a beer ,coffee or a bite to eat.It does not matter if it's winter,summer,autumn or spring,each season hold's it's own charm.A trip on the river cruisers is a much do,really interesting,you will take some fantastic photogragh's.If you go to Prinsengracht,you will remember it for a long time.

One of the three main canals. Lovel trip on the canal as part of our cruise, lots of beautiful house, as we were told quite expensive, mostly only available for rent to firm offices. Anyhow, amazing for the traveler's eye.

one of my favourite spot in the world. it is simply beautiful and rich....especially at nightthough I bet there are lots of junk thrown in the canals (like most canals in Amsterdam)but I still love it!

A stroll in the February sun. Take your time and look around and up and down, there is so much to see and so many places to call in to for a coffee or a beer. The canals are the life blood of Amsterdam.

Pleasant winter evening !. It was a chilly walk but the canals sights were just pleasant and relaxing. Lights coming from the amiable homes. Canal cruises tours cruising through the lighted bow canals. Romantic !
A MUST!. Walk this incredibly picturesque area of Amsterdam! A bike will make the trip too quick. Savor your time. A one of a kind experience not to be missed.

A Charming Walk with wonderful buildings by the water. We all enjoyed walking around this part of amsterdam. It was very picturesque and distinctly Dutch. I commented to my daughter that it looked very old fashioned with a horse and cart rambling by and people whizzing by on bicycles. I would have liked to have spent more time wandering around this area. The traditional vision of Amsterdam is encapsulated here. The trees, canals, bikes, architecture and coffee shops combine to create a relaxing and beautiful place
Lovely stroll. Lovely area to wander around and shoot pictures. Some cafes and shops, but the main point of walking three is to escape busy streets and enjoy the atmosphere.

Atmospheric. One of the three 'main' canals prisengracht is a great place to saunter and pass the time of day. Great to amble either day or night with good restaurants, bars and shops around - well worth a visit.

Prince of the canals. Although the entire Ams central area is fairy tale like with marvelous canals and waterways, the Prinsengracht is a little bit more charming as it is a little bit further from the very center. Therefore, it is a little bit calmer, more quite with pictoresque houses, cafees and relaxed atmosphere. Nice to stroll around and admire that beauty.
Prinsengracht. Do the Jordaan walking tour on the Tripadvisor City Guide, which starts on Prinsengracht. Worth a visit, particularly for the oldest pub in Amsterdam.
Happening place. Lots of shops and restaurants, definitely have to hit one of the cheese shops-free tastings-goat gouda is yum, easy access to tram running every couple minutes.
On foot. Walking around Amsterdam is a great delight, the main canals like this have fascinating and interesting architecture, also do wander around this area at night, really beautiful.

Great Place. Fantastic market on Saturdays, and amazing restaurants all around this area. Ann Franks house too and of course the canel it self which you can hire a boat and pedal or sail along. Great place to see Amsterdam rather than the bizy city centre. Great to stroll along and well recomended

Princes' street. Always a must strolling along Prinsengracht and the superb shops in the Jordan quarter of the town. From small independent eateries to la Tertulia Coffee Shop… a smart, quaint canal street.
A lovely stroll. This is one of the prettiest strolls in Amsterdam. Lots of great pic opportunities, architecture & scenery. Follow it along to the Anne Frank house.
canal tour along beautiful area. I took an hour canal tour that included this canal. lovely tour along the historic canal. period warehouses were very interesting and the tour was very good.

Picturesque, a must see!. This place is vibrant, it has everything from beautiful architecture to a bustling ALIVE feeling! I could have stayed here for hours just watching the goings on and taking photos galore. A wonderful place to relax, walk, eat and drink, people watch, shop ......and just stare at this canal with its barges Ah!!!

Unique. Amsterdams Canals are unmistakeable, they are instantly recognizable for their cobbled streets, bridges, cyclists reading their emails on their smart phones, and tall narrow brick houses with gables and hoists on the roovez. Wander around, stop in a bar or coffee shot and enjoy people watching.
Another Lovely Canal in Amsterdam. Lovely to walk along the canals of Amsterdam. Def worth a stroll. There's tons of activities, shops and restaurants to see. Pleasant just to walk along.

Famous Gracht. It was great to feel the typical athmosphere at the Prinsen Gracht. I think that the specificity of Amsterdam, comparable with the canals of Venice. And everywhere you can feel the urban life, a town full with young people, students and young families and all by bycicle, great!

If you are in A'dam, this is a must street to walk on.. My wife and I had a very romantic 4 night stay at an apartment on the street. we enjoyed our long night walks by the canal. As a cherry on top, the street has a very romantic dim lighting and great architecture for your eyes. So do bring your cameras along!
A must visit! Almost a Venice feel!

Pretty canal for a midday stroll. While we did not think this was *the* canal to see in Amsterdam, it is certainly in the top three. It's such a nice area for a leisurely walk, where you can admire the lovely architecture of the canal houses, varying styles of houseboats, and overall people watch. Many eateries line the canal so you can stop for a bite or drink pretty much any step of the way.

Beautiful canal side walk. The Princes canal is a waterway through old Amsterdam. Lots of beautiful of buildings and bridges to see if you are on foot or bike or on a canal tour boat. You will be bound to pass here if you are in the city for a couple of days.
A must visit.. One of the major canals flanked by unique architecture and equally unique shops/cafe's. Bring your camera and enjoy a slow walk.

My fav canal. Love this canal, just like the other 2 major canals of amsterdam. What makes it really nice is the fact that there more restaurants and cafes located on the strecth of the canal. Also, it borders the bohemian Jordaan.

Not like Venice. I heard a lot about Amsterdam, city of Canal. Prinsengracht is the best place to enjoy the stroll by the side of canals. We enjoyed old buildings, shops all across the canal. It is one of the happening place in Amsterdam. But I found Venice is good city of canal in the day whereas Prinsengracht comes to life in the evening.

Nice Place to Photograph. I visited in winter time (December 2014). I tremendously enjoyed walking around and photographing this place. Strongly recommended for people with an interest in photography.
Nice area for a walk. Great area to get a feel for the city. It is a little outside all of the excitement without being too far away

Breathtaking. Amsterdam is a city of canals and once you have been around the city you will actually feel that everything looks very similar and by similar I mean beautiful. Prinsengracht is undoubtedly one of the most b'ful canals running across the city. Tip off - do visit the canal after the sun sets, u would see amazing reflections in the water.

A tribute to the Dutch -------------. No one should miss taking at least one tour among the many available through the canal system, and spend some time considering the engineering and labor it took to create and maintain this canal system and the city constructed in conjunction with it and dependent upon it. All the streets and parkways are upon spoil pumped up from the bottom of the canals The changing scenery during a cruise ---- different buildings are sinking at rates dictated by the weight of the structure and the number and size of the pilings underneath ------ you can wear out a camera trying to catch all the constantly changing scenery---------------------

The Street Locals Recomment. This area is apparently highly recommended by the locals and no wonder, it is yet another beautiful location to visit in Amsterdam! There is the beautiful buildings, the scenery and numerous shops to visit and however you visit this area, its equally as amazing!

You've been hard press to actually miss this.. After obtaining a city map you'll notice that the canals around Amsterdam are hard to miss. Not do these canal bring the city to life, as they are iconic, beautiful etc but they are were very useful to me as indicators as street signs were only available at the intersections and very high up on buildings or just hard to find sometimes. They aren't clean by any stretch of the imagination but overall can create a good breeze.
The Street the Locals Chose. Lots of love views and great boutique/retro shops - very pretty at night in the winter and probably even nicer in the summer.
Beautiful Area. Wow beautiful area, buildings and houses! Many canal tours. Few cafes and resturants. Bike paths. Liek a maze you can go round and round....we did

Great strolling down the canal. We could not get enough of the scenery; between the architecture. the canals, the boats, the birds, and the people watching!
We saw many cute shops that sold local items, and being after Christmas, got some great deals.
Wear comfortable shoes, because of the cobblestone streets.

Fantastic canal to walk along. Walking all the Prinsengracht and Keisersgracht are musts for those who love architecture and the romance of the canals. Walk them day and evening and on both sides to see all the fantastic architecture. You will not be disappointed.
Great stroll and wander. Love this area of Amsterdam - away from the madness of Dam Square etc, but still has a great choice of cafes, shops, restaurants and bars.

Another Lovely Canal Street. There are a number of canal streets like Prinsengracht like Herengracht, and Singel that are the main arteries of Old Amsterdam. This street rings the old section and begins near the train station and runs around to Amstel - the old original part of the city. Along this street are rows of houses spanning the 16th - 20th century perfectly preserved. The street crosses many other streets and so there are many bridges along the way. You can find all sorts of stores, restaurants, cafes and bars and this street will carry you to nearly everywhere you want to visit in the city.
other "Grachten" are also charming. Amsterdam is full of "grachten". Some offer a nicer scenery than others. It's a matter of taste.Prinsengracht is a very big a busy one.
really pretty. Nice for a long summers walk :) lovely views and lots of character around the streets. Nice markets dotted around too

nice canal walk. an OK canal walk/ nothing special, but very nice. The street is said to have great shopping which I found just OK, however the views along the canal are quite nice. Amsterdam is a good walking city.

Lovely street. This is a very lovely street. Very centrally located. Our hotel (Pulitzer Hotel) was excellent. The views all along this area, especially over in the Jordaan section are worth visiting. Tulip Museum and Cheese Museum are worth a visit, but don't go out of your way to get there.
Well worth a wander down Prinsengracht. Take time out to walk along this canal - watch people on their bikes, shopping etc. Fabulous buildings, attractive shops.
Great shoppong. This is area is wonderful for people watching, shopping and eating. A lot to see and a nice place to stroll.
Nice buildings. One of the historical canals of Amsterdam. Very nice buildings along it. Rent a bike and take a tour along the canal.

Prinsengracht is the gateway of the canal district!. Prinsengracht is the longest and final canal of Amsterdam's ring of canals. This canal is also the gateway to the other (outer) parts of the city of Amsterdam (including: the Jordaan and the Oud Zuid, and Amsterdam Noord region). One may easily get to many destinations within this canal such as The Anne Frank House, Cheese Museum, Monet museum, Westerkirk, Tulip Museum. This canal is much quieter and more relaxing than the canals closer to the city center and has more locals strolling the streets. Great place to have a drink at a brown cafe and people watch.
romantic. don't miss the walk along prinsengracht! and on it there is a good design store (the frozen fountain) to pop into as well.
Lovely walk. A lovely walk along the canal, There are nice cafés and some places to get a bite to eat. Certainly a relaxing part of the holiday.
A beautiful canal. Walk along the canal, see the Anne frank house. You'll find cafes and shops on the streets that are perpendicular to the canal

Beautiful canal to walk along. Our hotel faced this canal, which radiates round the centre of Amsterdam, and it was lovely to look out of the window and see the houseboats and restaurant boats moving along, and the houses all along the canal are individual, with amazing gables and huge windows. Some have steps up to the front door, and most have cellars, which must be below the water line. There are many bridges along this canal, which offer photo opportunities, and at night they are lit up. It is atmospheric and delightful. The cobbled streets are narrow, with one way traffic, and more bikes than cars come along, so you have to keep your wits about you, and keep on the narrow pavements!

Amsterdam December 2014. Enjoyed my visit here on a glass top boat trip which I believe was 9Euro for 1 hour. I found Amsterdam to be a very clean city, felt safe at all times and enjoyed admiring the character of the architecture. I never visited the 'seedy' area (not for me), but the flower market was large (would love to see it in the summer), There was a small Christmas Market (10 stalls) mainly food. I would definitely return to Amsterdam. I particularly found the whole concept of very few cars and thousands of bicycles quiet a curiosity, so very easy to get about on foot unlike other cities.

Pleasant and convenient area. We stayed in a vacation rental with a garden here and it was lovely. Beautiful area for strolling (though watch out for the bicycles because the sidewalks are quite narrow), and so convenient and pleasant for walking everywhere we wanted to go that the only time we took a bus in the city was upon our initial arrival, to get there from the train station. Great area for people-watching over tea/coffee/beer in one of the sidewalk cafes.
So pleasant. This is such a nice area, you can walk for hours, just looking at the fantastic architecture. Also so many lovely shops and cafes to try, there just was not enoguh time!!

Great walk at night. Many top attractions and restaurants can be found by this pretty canal. When people picture Amsterdam, this is the ideal image that comes to mind. Stop for a moment to take it all in.
Nice area.... Really well maintained part of the city, and seemingly a very classy one - stayed on this street in the andaz hotel, highly recommend the shops nearby too

nice street to stay on. I stayed on this street in a vacation flat and I enjoyed my stay here. Just up the road is the Anne Frank house and Monet museum. This is one of the main outer canal streets of Amsterdam and a perfect launch point to see the entire city.

“must do”. If you are travelling for the first time to this beautiful city then I suggest you join this boat trip that will take you among others to the homeboat museum, Anne Frank House and the tulip museum. The tour lasts one hour and if you do it during the nighttime with all those lights, it will feel like you are part of a movie set.
Most romantic body of water. This is one of the major canals in Amsterdam the buildings along the canal are purely enchanting the most beautiful you can see.
Beautiful. stunning canal and beautiful houses, take a walk, take a drink, relax and people watch to your hearts content

Scenic and serene. Really beautiful area of Amsterdam. Lined with canals and beautiful houses, biking by Prinsengracht is a great experience. Lots of great places to eat at, since it is very close to the Amsterdam city centre. Good accessibility by trams.
What a lovely part of Amsterdam. One of the best chill in my life. I've spend quite some time in this area, every part is very good!!
Beautifull. Lots of houses around the "grachten" Beautifull at the evening. Prinsengracht is the longest gracht in Amsterdam

where we stayed. we stayed in this area for our trip in Nov 2014, it was beautiful! Felt very safe to walk around in at night, not far from Anne Frank museum, lots of little boutiques and places to eat. Very pretty area.

Fun to walk the Canals. We were in Amsterdam from November 14 through November 16 and we walked everywhere. It was simply delightful to walk along the canals in the day and in the night. Prinsengracht was a canal where the Anne Frank House was located and (because I got lost in finding the House) we walked a long way along this canal. It is mostly a residential area and we walked it at night. It was chilly but it was still delightful and romantic to walk it with my bride of 46 years.

Lovely area along the canal. We stayed at an apartment a half a block off of Prinsengracht and spent a lot of time walking up and down the avenue as well as taking a canal cruise along Prinsengracht. There are many local shops, restaurants and coffee shops along the way. It is absolutely gorgeous with many picture taking opportunities. Architecture is incredible. Highly recommend walking or biking the entire street.

One of Amsterdam's most beautiful canal walks.. My wife and I did this walk kind of by accident while on our way to food tour and absolutely loved every step. There were so many things to look at and enjoy.

The heart of Amsterdam. What can I say about the Prisengracht that isn't already in the title of this review: it is the beating heart of this vibrant and refreshing city where bicycles rush past and the canals beckon. Everything you need is in the area or immediately off it on Heregracht and Kiesengracht.. When you go to Amsterdam,you will leaves your heart on the Prisengracht .
PLEASANT AREA. Nice walking by the canals. restaurants are intermitten, and some red light windows are also there. but at night with the light shimmering off the water, omg
Beautiful neighbourhood. Beautiful architecture. Lovely little shops. A worthwhile walk through Amsterdam. Strolled through in the early evening.
Beautiful canal walks. Spacious tree lined canal walk leading up to the Anne Frank House. It is quiet and has some nice mansion houses.
Ambiance. The Prinsengracht makes you feel like you're walking in a movie. Want to feel like a superstar? go there
Nice canal. Long street and canal, with a lot of beautiful houses, boats, houseboats and interesting things to see.Next is the Jordaan district, clean, quiet and nice.

great to experience. ... and its free. Just wandering along the well-kept canal side is a unique experience in all seasons. Helpful if you have a guide book to pinpoint architectural details of the canal-side houses.
Historical buildings. I liked everything about it the ,canals , beautifull bridges , the people the atmosphere , the restaurants and coffee houses .
Beautiful Canal. Very charming canal with beautiful houses with Big Windows and Doors. Nice and quiet at night. Anne Frank House and Pancake Bakery are highly recommended on Prinsengracht.

Nice canal in amsterdam. This seems very long and also called as mother of all canals, this is also should be a must visit place while you are in amsterdam because amsterdam without a canal is nothing,,,

Another view of Amsterdam. Beautiful architecture, tree lines canals and the stunning Westerkerk church near Anne Frank House are just a few of the highlights around this street. Take your time and go down the smaller streets off to the side to feel the real Amsterdam. Stop for a drink or a light lunch or come back for a nice dinner. Take good walking shoes as from here you can walk to many other sites in this beautiful city.
Amsterdam unique in its kind!. Walk this part of Amsterdam and experience freedom in all its aspects. Also discovering the canals by boat is worth wile.

Picturesque. Perfect place to stroll and have coffee along the canals. Different time of day you will see different colors of the canal. Do take the canal cruise for an overall cruise tour. Need not say, this is a must

Can't miss it.. I didn't realize that this was actually an attraction located on tripadvisor. Walking through amsterdam you'll encounter numerous canals. This one is the biggest however and the face of Amsterdam.
Another great wander. Amsterdam is a great walking city. I wandered through here and found great character and cool shops and galleries. But watch for bikes!
Stayed at Pulizer Hotel. Nice location good clean hotel with attentive service. Very good breakfast. Walking distance from 9 streets.
Great to walk along. Walking along the Prinsengracht in the morning with a coffee was lovely. Beautiful canal outside of the very centre of Amsterdam

Quintessential Amsterdam. While others prefer the Herrengracht, we preferred the Prinsengracht. It is more down-to-earth that the ritzy Herrengracht, and every bit as picturesque. When I think Amsterdam, I think of the Prinsengracht. In addition to the Anne Frank House, it also has the Pancake House!

Worth while. A must do! The tour though the city must be done on a boat, the canals are a great way of getting a taste of the architecture and structure of the whole place. You get to see a lot of nice spots when you go on the tour, you also get tons of information about Amsterdam and its history.If you want to walk do it at night, it is quite beautiful.

Don't miss it when in Amsterdam. This canal is part of the three famous ring canals of Amsterdam, Herengracht, Keizersgracht and Prinsengracht.Many museums are located on these three canals, but walking half a day along the water means walking in a 17th century museum at no cost. These days, there are only few cars roaming around in this area, but if you have kids with you, beware of bullet bikes that seem to be coming from nowhere.This being said, the walk is really enjoyable, and many cafes are on the way for a quick stop in a real Dutch atmosphere.However, before starting this tour, I would strongly advise to visit the Grachten Museum (located on Herengracht, near Leidsestraat). I am happy I did it, because it explains quite well how, when and why the canals were built. There are also many house reproductions and it is possible to look at their interior through peep holes.

Magnificent View.... Your visit will never be complete in Amsterdam if you don't visit at least one of the major canals. Strolling along this canal during fall was absolutely magical. Better still, do it with your partner, it is very romantic. Stop by one of the many cafes along the canal and watch the world goes by with a cold beer or a hot coffee. Watch out for the speedy bicycles though, you are most likely to be knocked down them then cars.
big canal. very long canal surrounding the amterdam, did canal cruise from this canal, love it. this is also one of the main canal to complete the canal map of amsterdam.
Beautiful view. Walking down this stretch of street/canal gives you a beautiful view. Perfect for a leisure walk. Just be careful of the busy cycling traffic.
Excellent. Wonderful to walk along, just relax and have a beer or coffee in one of the canal side cafes. Quintessential Amsterdam.
cute canal street. One of the must-see sights in the Old Amsterdam area with cobblestone streets, 17th Century canals, bridges and houses.
Beautiful Canal. Lovely canal with good shopping and some museums. It is really lovely to walk right along the canal from one end to the other. Beware of cyclists coming up behind you!

A canal trip was most enjoyable. We went on a circular trip on a canal boat. The commentary provided via headphones with a choice of many languages, was good and clear. Very informative. It was sheltered so we appreciated the views even though it was raining.
Lovely spot. Lovely spot, but nothing to talk home about... Amsterdam is full of canals and buzzing with people. If I had to choose, for the best views and photos, I'd choose Utrecht every time...

Beautiful Canal. It's just beautiful. We spent hours and days wandering around. We kept dipping in and out. The houses and boats are beautiful and it's so chilled. Lovely places to stop for a drink and food too

Nice Walk. Can be crowded at times - Go early morning to avoid that.
A nice area for a walk and a chance to appreciate the local architecture.
Watch out for the bikes - They are lethal !
beautiful. Beautiful canal, very photogenic.like everywhere in amsterdam, beware of cyclists, they seem to have right of way everywhere, and they stop for nothing

Best location !!. Prinsengracht spans the best of the Jordaan area and 9 streets and takes you from Anne Franks house to the Museums. The houses are beautiful, the whole feel of this canal is perfect.. No dislikes. Restaurants, grocery stores directly off it, so pedestrian friendly.

Magical place to while away an evening.. Just stand there over the Prinsengracht leaning against a bridge rail for a good while. Watch the hundreds of bicyclers go by -- couples with one riding the handlebars; parents with children hanging on like pro bike hanger-onners; older women fashionably dressed in heels and beautiful capes; young adults accelerating with legs long and fit, torsos so straight; everyone happily going somewhere all hours of the day and night. Watch evening fall and the lights of layered bridges come up, canal boats and party dingoes running silently underneath. Breathe in the clean, just-washed darkness after a flower-power shower. Smell the greatness wafting from every open door -- good food, good bud. Hear laughter and singing so vibrant you can almost taste the beer they're drinking. It's magic. It's Amsterdam.
Great walk along the canal. Lovely area for a walk and a great place to see traditional Dutch architecture. Lots of places to stop by for a cup of coffee or a beer.

Lovely canal scene. We must of walked up and down this canal loads of times on our long weekend visit...watch out for the bikes, you don't hear them coming. First thing Sunday morning is fantastic, especially if the sun is shining. Stop at one of the Cafe's and soak up the atmosphere.

Great area!. Best Canal area - great food, shops and vibe! It is one of the three most importat canals in AMS - and has the best shops and restaurants there are plenty of food options from cafes, to modern cuisine at every intersection or over each bridge

typical Amsterdam. A walk along the Prinsengracht, with all these different, old, beautiful warehouses that are being converted to (very expensive) living houses, and those floating houses in the canal itself....wow! You really get a taste of the real Amsterdam; a combination between Middle Ages and Present Time.
Beautiful. Definitely take one of the night time tour of this , or any canal in Amsterdam. I like the night tours best. The city lights make it that much more scenic.

Picture perfect. What to say. One of several parallel canals and picture perfect. I suggest take a canal cruise, but also great to walk the canal paths.

take a ride on the on-off boats. You can ride both Keisersgracht and Prinzengracht by taking the inexpensive on-off canal boats. Pleasant, peaceful and informative. Great way to get acquainted with Amsterdam.

one of the many great hubs in Amsterdam. a city-view that is excellent and full of history as many of the canals in the city. This canal as much as any other features the grandeur of the Golden Age of Dutch history
Great walk along the canal. Walking along this street takes you through the main areas of Amsterdam and some of the quieter areas which have beautiful canal side houses and restaurants.
Beautiful and iconic. The canal boat tour is a must. I've been to Amsterdam a couple of times and I do the canal boat tour every time!

One of the quieter streets with older canal houses.. if you like taking pictures of unique architectural designs on the roofs and fronts of houses, head down on Prinsengracht towards the Amstel or better yet take a canal cruise, they go there all day and part of the night.

Great Canal. The walk along the canal was great. Went in to the Tulip museum, learne a lot about it.A really beautiful canal to stroll or ride along with plenty of places to eat and drink.Also good for some shopping.

Nice and memorable.. The canal itself was very picturesque, and not only this, there were many historical building around.There was the Amstel in the East, the Westerkerk church and Anne Frank House. Each and every location had its own charm and made a brilliant line.
Central but quite. Good area to stay when in Amsterdam. Very much central, close to each and every attraction. At the same time - quite and cozy.

This is the Number One canal for me. This is my favourite canal and during our last few visits we have stayed at hotels on this canal. Great architecture with some interesting museums, restaurants etc.
Nice walk. Nice to walk along this canal to see local life, nice views, small shops etc. Worth taking the time to explore.
A Great Walk & Views. Well worth walking along this canal lovely views especially in the Autumn and bring your camera too.

Unexpected fun on Prinsengracht!. We took a lovely and romantic stroll down this thoroughfare. The architecture is stunning. The homes are welcoming and cozy looking. We were delighted to encounter a woman living here who had befriended a huge heron!

Fantastic. The best canal street in Amsterdam, joining the 9 streets, and every party in Amsterdam has it's core here. Gay Pride, Queen's day (now king's day), Grachten festival, etc.Can be a bit full of tourist but definitely a must when visiting this awesome city

Lovely place to stay at. had the privilege of staying in a cosy apartment in this lovely street. Nice and quiet and talking walks at night between the canals is a true pleasure. Has some nice cafes and small boutiques and it's quite near to the centre and the dam square.

The prince's canal. A really good way to see the city is to walk or hire a bike and go from one end of the horse shoe shaped canals to the other. The Prince's canal or Prinzengracht has lots of bars , coffeshops and hotels dotted along the way to stop and enjoy.

Best Canal. Prinsengracht is the best canal to stay on. In the middle of everything. Supermarket, restaurants, in the heart of the city. Within walking distance to all parts of the city. Anne Frank House on this canal.

A beautiful street. Amsterdam is a beautiful city and this area is a delightful place to wander. The old buildings are very atmospheric. There are good museums nearby but walking is just as pleasurable

watching Prinsengracht. just enjoyed walking the whole area, looking at shops and people and dodging bikes! our hotel looked out on an intersection that provided wonderful breakfast entertainment...watching people zipping by on bikes holding umbrellas, talking on phones, drinking coffee, etc....is everyone in amsterdam born with an innate sense of balance!?

Beautiful Canal. Before joining the tour as we arrive one day ahead we booked our hotel is along Prinsengracht. Little did I know that this is one of the major canals of Amsterdam. A great way to spend the day taking the scenic route. I walked Prinsengracht a number of times and discovered something new every time I walked the canal and shops area. If you walk about a 3 mile stretch you are able to see quite a bit! There are some fun pubs and cafes along the way and of course many tourist attractions that can form large crowds. If you duck in and out of the alleys you can find some really great shops!
Lovely architecture. This street/canal is lined with really lovely buildings. A great place to stroll, take in the atmosphere and watch traffic on the canal.

Lots to see. Probably one of the liveliest of canals, there is a lot to see on Prinsengracht. Anne Frank House should be the top of anyone's list (I suggest getting tickets a couple months ahead of time to avoid long line up, you can see my review of this). There is also the Amsterdam Tulip House (which I'll have to see next time), the Houseboat Museum (that was neat, see my review on that), and Westkerk Church, built 1622 (see my review).Plenty of restaurants to choose from and you can sit outside people watching and admiring the canal. I patronized Cafe Marcella (see my review on that) and Cafe Kalkhoven (see my review on one of oldest in Amsterdam). Unfortunately it was still raining when I was at this cafe to sit outside but I sat by the window enjoying the view.Prinsengracht is between five or ten minute (well depends on fast or slow you go) walk from Dam Square (see my review on the square).Make sure you have comfortable walking shoes and don't forget the camera!Depending on what you want to see, I'd bank on at least three hours maybe more exploring what Prinsengracht has to offer. It took about 45 minutes to an hour to go through Anne Frank's House.I was on one of end Prinsengracht one day as I explored areas near then a couple days later on the other end.

Another canal. I am writing this as the Canal and not the hotel! Being the 3rd canal in the series, and despite being called 'Princes Canal' this isn't the posh canal - that in fact is Herengracht! However Prinsengracht does have some lovely architecture around it and as the longest of the 3 major cross sections it is the one to have a long afternoon stroll along. It has some of the more notable locations on it including the Noordermarkt (Northern Market), Anne Frank House and the Westerkerk (Western Church, Amsterdam's tallest church).

bars. near leidseplein lots of bars and night-life on the leidseplein itself

Romantic. My husband and I took a traditional boat trip (rondvaart) on the Prinsengracht. If you are interested in culture and history, you should absolutely do the same. You get to see Amsterdam, and get to know a lot of history of the city. This city has so much history!
It's beautiful

Gay Pride Canal Parade is on the Amstel River, Too.. This is a unique experience that the entire city, plus tourists, join in with. The solidarity of everyone in the city with the gay community is commendable. Literally thousands of people line Prinsengracht and Amstel and the bridges over those waterways to watch the boats and floats go by. Only 80 entrants are chosen annually from industries, banks and private groups which apply. Several hundred people man the floats, some of which look precariously over-full. On board there are men, women and men who appear to be women. Binoculars help in that game. We did not plan to be in Amsterdam for Gay Pride, but we are very glad that it worked out this way, because this event is so "one of a kind". Boaters stake out their viewing location days in advance. Those on foot choose their viewing locations hours in advance. One day there's empty space and the next morning 10 boats have tied up to watch the Canal Parade. You don't have to be gay to enjoy this event. It's very entertaining for everyone. This is the best free entertainment you can find in A'dam. The floating parade entrants start arriving around 11 AM, and by about 1:30 the parade starts from Prinsengracht near the Jordaan. It is more like 2 PM or later by the time the first floats make it up Amstel and beyond, towards Centraal Station. The entire parade of the 80 boats, plus assorted hangers-on, goes on till nearly 6 PM, and the party continues into the evening with loud music and lots of pedestrians all around the parade route. Even the tram service was suspended on at least the 4, 9 and 14 lines, that we know of, and quite likely others. Now, 4 hours after the Canal Parade ended, the trams are still not running yet. This is a big holiday here in Holland. There are portable toilets in many locations along the parade route and venders, especially of food and gay-friendly paraphenalia, are ubiquitous. The police presence is enormous. The crowd was super-friendly and totally non-violent, so the presence, for example, of "paddy wagons" to take away those who might be arrested was totally unnecessary.

Picturesque. We stayed at a hotel on Prinsengracht a half block south of the Ann Frank House. Very picturesque. Took a canal boat ride to really see the area---best way to see the canals. We saw one old house that was leaning a bit---tilting at windmills, I suppose.

Most beautiful canal. This was our favorite canal in Amsterdam. walking all the way from Anne Frank's house down and around to the Amstel river. There are lots of riverside cafes along the canal where you can enjoy a quiet drink or snack. Absolutely lovely.
We took a river cruise. It was very interesting to see the tall and narrow buildings that are so common in Amsterdam. We were fortunate to have very nice weather during our visit.

Lovely. Very scenic, lovely houses and beautiful canal
Enjoy a coffee next to the gracht and watch the boates pass by
excellent. you can walk or ride a bike by the princegracht,nice to see cool shops, arcitecture, there are many restaurants, coffe shops for dining or having lunch with locals

Central location. Very long walk along the canal, short walk to floating tulip market, great cafes, Reichsmuseum and Bols experience. Ann Frank house almost next door but long queues so advance booking is important.
Prisengracht. One of the three main canals, dug in the 17th century during the Dutch Golden Age, form concentric belts around the city.

Picture perfect Amsterdam. We walked along Prinsengracht, Keizergracht and Herengracht a couple days ago. Very pretty canals with lots of photo ops. Nice shops and cafes. My teenage girls were ecstatic to find the bench from the key scene in "The Fault in the Stars" movie and I was thrilled to locate a few spots were Ocean's 12 scenes were filmed.
Lovely Walk along the Canal. We stayed at the Pulitzer Hotel on this canal, and it was a delight to be able to get out in the mornings and walk along its sidewalks and bridges.

Stroll along and nice shopping. When weather is good one can spend days on the canals, strolling shopping and sipping a drink watching boats pass by. Check out the 'negen straatjes' area between singel and prinsengracht which is full of trendy boutiques. Enjoy!

Walk Along the Canal. I enjoyed the afternoon stroll along the Prinsengracht Canal. I stopped and toured the Anne Frank House. You can purchase tickets for a boat road on the canal at a shop at the endvof the block on which the Anne Frank House is located.

Good area to walk around and it takes you through many parts of the city. Our hotel was at one end of the Prisengracht and it provided a great way of orienting yourself and moving along through the different parts of the, past shops, restaurants and tourist attractions.
Worth walking along to look at the range of houses and warehouses

A typical part of Amsterdam!. Go there on a beautiful summer evening, and walk the whole lenght from the north up to the flowermarket, you will not regret it! Lots of little boutique shops, lovely and cozy little bars, coffee shops and restaurants, lotsof beUtiful houses and houseboats!!
Beautiful canal-scapes and interesting shopping.. A great place to wander. Many interesting shops. We visited Anne Frank House and wondered in this area for a few hours.

just lovely!. A lovely canal with picturesque houses on either side of it. We visited an antique shop which sells coffee and juices. The best coffee in Amsterdam from Italy. A lovely place to wander along and relax at your own pace, watch out for the bikes whizzing past a must for every visit the the city

Amsterdam is the Canals!. Looking back on our time in Amsterdam, many visuals come to mind, I photographed the canals over and over. They are interesting to shop, walk, dine , cross over the bridges and so beautiful in the different lights of the amsterdam sky.

see it by foot rather than boat. because its so lovley - elegant interestin houses, cafes and bars, locals on their bikes
walk all the way to the end and then along the next one
great!

Lovely precinct. There are two ways to enjoy this stylish area of Amsterdam. One is to travel down the canal and see the houses and buildings from water level - the Old Town needs to be seen from water level. The other is to take a leisurely walk along the paths beside the canal. The advantage of walking is that you can stop and look. We enjoyed both.
Beautiful Canals. These gorgeous canals really shape the major beauty of the Amsterdam old city center. It would be a shame to visit and not walk around them for photos.
Awesome canals. I rented a houseboat right across from the Noorde Market. It was great to see all of the water traffic on the canal. The homes and shops are all perfect like a picture.
Picturesque canal. Not far from the Freeland. All the canals do look a bit samey though. Go first thing in the morning for perfectly still water and mirror like reflections.

The prettiest canal. This canal is long and has many unique shops,coffee bars and photo opportunities.it is at the southern end of the famous 9 streets area and for all these reasons is well worth a visit.
Rent a room there, that is the best. It's nice to explore at day and at night, it is beutiful but not touristy. Rent a room there, that is the best!
Nice walk. We walked around the canal and it was very pretty, It was nice to see all the different types of houses.

it never sleeps. We stayed in Prinsengracht canal narrowboat and it was`at the heart of everything, lots of night life, little artisan shops and places to eat. The atmosphere was wonderful, check out when the canal festival takes place, which is like party in the park only iis on teh canal and what a spectactular event!! Worth choosing to visit on this occasion!!downside - Amsterdam is expensive use Albert Hein Supermarkets if self cater they offer good value.on the Plus there is a Macdonalds on nearly every corner so you can get cheaper meals !!Do explore the side streets they offer better value and are safe to wander.

Beautiful architecture. We had the opportunity to go inside some of the buildings on Prinsengracht during the open garden festival. Well worth strolling along the side of the canal to see the buildings or taking a boat cruise to hear more about the buildings.

Nice walk close to Museums. After visiting the Anne Frank House we decided to go over here very beautiful area in the sunshine and it's quite near the tulip and cheese museums which wasn't opened when we got there so we enjoyed walking around here. Canal is very pretty.

Beautiful walk. We visited in May, lovely weather so more conducive to walking around & exploring! This is a beautiful canal, cafes & restaurants and some small museums (Tulip and Cheese, both of which are worth a short visit) and of course, Anne Frank House. Lots of the canal tours stop off here, we had a nice glass of wine from the bar just next to AFH sitting on the tables on the canal-side. Beautiful buildings.
A beautiful walk. This is a beautiful area to walk around. Plus it is free. This is reminiscent of Amsterdam and give this place it's beauty and character.

Stayed here an a houseboat. Lovely area of Amsterdam, lots of bars and places to eat. There was a great market on Saturday which had everything from fruit and fish to secondhand and new clothes! Was noisy at night when we were on the boat but worth a walk if nr by
Amsterdam canals. This a nice place to walk. The Ann Frank house is in this neighborhood. There are century old buildings along side of new construction. The newer buildings blend in very well.

Relax Time. One of the best things you must do when visiting Amsterdam is taking a walk or even a boat tour by the canals. Don't expect smelly or polluted water: all the city canals have their water cleaned every three days! Quite impressive! You could even swim on it, but it is not allowed.It's very interesting to notice the way of life of the near-by residents of the Amsterdam canals. They simply sit by the canal, chat a little, some have their boats for a ride, others even do barbecue on the boat with their friends! So different from the busy city center (Dam).And, of course, bicicles everywhere. It's Netherland, after all.Prinsengracht is one of the famous canals from Amsterdam. You will find there the tradicional houses architecture and bridges. It's a good idea to do the boat tour. You will have access to a lot of information about the canals and the city.Enjoy it!

Very posh glimpse into the past. I love walking along Prinsengracht everytime I go to Amsterdam. The houses are incredible (and super-expensive). There are shops along this canal along the side streets that sell stuff you can't get anywhere else in the world.
Great for accomodation. An excellent accomodation choice giving an easy walk to many tourist attractions, restaurants, etc. Liked being "in the heart" of Amsterdam and enjoying the canal environment.
Walked 9 miles a day!. Great place to enjoy hour walking. Beast canal for many things,from Anne Frank Huis to the plazas. you can get a boat tour there.
Great walk. Our hotel was on this canal so we walked along it quite a bit. Very picturesque. Lots of cafe on the route. There is also the tulip museum and cheese museum on this route.

Crowd, flower, bikes and cannals. It is a very nice place to visit. Be prepared to walk a lot, or go by bike. Forget about cars. You would not be able to drive through the streets, which are in fact very narrow. Best choice for crowded days or first time travelers is to go by metro.

Great place to walk but filthy dirty. Great to walk along and view the architecture, the canal and the shops.However as with most of Amsterdam it was filthy dirty especially with fast food rubbish.Amsterdam really needs to sort out the filth that is on its streets.

Great place to walk if there isn't a rubbish strike!. Fabulous old buildings all with individual character, but we were most unlucky to be there with mounds of rubbish stacked almost head high in places. With the warm weather the flies were out. I'm sure it would normally be well worth the walk. Take your camera and look for the quirky corners.
Lovely. Very picturesque and quiet, and I especially loved the flock of wild parakeets that flew past my bedroom window!
The best way to experience Amsterdam. Walking along the canals, seeing the houseboats close up, seeing all the people and bikes and the variety of restaurants.

Another stroll in the Jordaan. Prinsengracht is the next canal over from Herengracht both canals traverse the Jordaan area of Amsterdam and will eventually guide you to the Anne Frank House and the lines that extend from its entrance. One of the real pleasures of Amsterdam is the opportunity to walk through some beautiful canal bordered neighborhoods and admire the architecture(and the leaning row houses that are shifting on their foundations) and the peace and tranquility away from the Dam Square and Newmarket/Oude Kerk areas. The Prinsengracht is also home to some excellent restaurants and canal side cafés that offer a nice respite after your walk. Make sure to stay on the sidewalk and avoid the bike paths or risk incurring the wrath of the Amsterdamers as they speed along to or from work.
romantic walks. loved this area. was very romantic walking along the tree lined canal with lovely little pavement cafes and bars along the way. great for people watching. very relaxing.

Beautiful beautiful Amsterdam. What a way to celebrate our 10 year wedding anniversary. Absolute bliss to arrive in Schipol airport, taxi waiting, ready to be transported to our hotel. Prinsegracht was high on our to do list and we were not disappointed. The operator took us on a slow ride and it was very informative. Absolutely wonderful to cruise on the canals and see life from a different perspective. Want to do it again!

a few place are nice but go to Keizersgracht or Herengracht. Prinsengracht is the least interesting of the canals in Amsterdam. Only go there when there are main events on the canal.
