Beautiful place to wander!. When we got off the train we were hit by a wall of weed and sex shops. We didnt expect it right out of the station. When we found the anne frank house and prinsengracht we loved how quiet and awesome it was. The locals on their bikes zipping by looked like a constant moto gp race

Fabulous area. Stayed here for a week, last week. Perfect place to come back and relax after a hectic Museum day. Has restaurants, bruin cafes, sandwich shops, supermarket everything! And only a very short walk to all the attractions.

Prinsengracht. A beautiful canal. Stroll along on a sunny day and sit and let the world go by as you drink a coffee in one of the many cafes.
Such a relaxing city!

Lovely area. We walked along the canal from near the train station through the Jordaan to the museum district. Very peaceful and a lovely area to stroll.
Stopped for some lunch and a glass of wine, then watched as the people of Amsterdam floated by on all kinds of vessels on this lazy Sunday afternoon. Just great.

Great place to stroll. We stayed at the Pulitzer located on this canal street. Strolling here gives you a nice taste of old Amsterdam architecture. It's nearby the Jordaan that is loaded with shops, cafe's and restaurants.

Great shop, great cheese. We were spending the week-end in Amsterdam and I was determined to bring cheese home back to the states. There are several cheese shops located all around Amsterdam and in the department stores, which are very good, a bit pricey, but again, the same brand shop is all over. I shouted w glee when we ran into the Cheese Museum, which a across the canal and down 1 block from the Anne Frank House. The minute I walked in I thought to myself, "Yes, something different . This is what I was looking for." An older gentleman was dressed in traditional clothing of the Nederlands, wooden shoes and all. But, he was there to answer any of your questions, give you samples and of course, sell cheese. The prices were about 3E less for similiar sized cheeses from the other shops. Also, being the cheese is purchased from the cheese museum, any of it could be brought back to the states, so they said. There is a cheese museum downstairs which is 2 E and gives you a 10% discount on your purchase, so figure out if its worth going to it or not. I spent a long time in the shop. Ate tons of cheese and purchased 2 rounds, which they vacuum seal for you for your travels. How fun!

lovely to see. Prinsengracht is a lovely place with the flower market close by, canals and of course shopping, and a number of trams run through here to/ from Centrall station, Dam Square and Ledelsplein

Good place to know real Amsterdam. This place has a charm and it does reflect the famous Dutch history. Just round the corner, you can see flea market (only over the weekends, I assume) and that adds to the charm in the city.This place has a character and to me and helped me understand why the Dutch were so excellent sailors and fantastic warriors. There is nothing to visit in particular, I would recommend to take some time off and just stroll around. You will never feel disappointed.Another unique part is that you can rent boats at this place - there may be other places where you can rent the boat and explore the vast network of canals, but it was really a good sight to see young couples together on boats moving around. This was the first place where I noticed traffic lights for boats and later I saw in Hamburg (Germany) also.Do not miss this place. It has a charm, a character and a lot to offer.

Lovely canal for a stroll!. I always enjoy a stroll along the Prisengracht. The Prinsengracht (Prince's Canal), dug in the 17th century, is the longest of the three main canals in Amsterdam. It is named after the Prince of Orange. Most of the canal houses along the Prisengracht were built during the Dutch Golden Age.There are many cafes and pubs located along the canal as well as the Anne Frank House, the Westerkirk, the Noordermarkt, and the Noorderkerk. Additionally, the bridges over the Prinsengracht canal connect with the Jordaan (don't miss the 9 little streets).

A beautiful view morning and evening.. We have a VRBO on this canal, makes us feel like we live here. I would always return .Our little place has a private patio with lovely garden. entry is on the street level, right out to the canal. There is a nice kitchen and a washing machine. Owners live upstairs.

My favorite part of Amsterdam. This canal is the best part of Amsterdam to explore. I spent an entire day going up and down the streets and bridges over the Prinsengracht. There are many great sites in this area, including the Anne Frank Huis. Definitely go!
Famous canal. This is one of the biggest and also most famous canal in Amsterdam. There is also something happening there, at any time of the day or season of the year.

The Better Canal For Normal Life In Amsterdam. This canal is one of the nicer in Amsterdam. I recommend it for a quick stroll and to see how people live in Amsterdam. It is a few streets out off Damrak. You will see many small cafes, maybe a window or two, and normal life. You may see someone moving into their new apartment using the steel beam at the top of the house with a pulley to move large furniture in through the windows. You will come across bakeries with fresh breads and may small unique family owned shops. I suggest about a 20 minute walk along this canal to tie into your walking tour.During Queensday this canal is one of the most crowded canals.

Cracking Canal. Of all the canals, this one is probably my favourite. On the far edge of the main canal ring, walk round Prinsengracht for a peaceful and picturesque canalside wander. Look out for coffee shop Tertulia on your way if that is your thing.

Have a nice walk there. The Pinsengracht is worth a walk on a smooth suny day. Enjoy the view of antique buildings, the bikes going through, the antique shops, the boats going through the canal. Typical view of Amsterdam, worth a time out.
It's should be on your must-go list. You can only see such exceptional view in Amsterdam. Canals, bicycles and boat houses all combine together. so
Do it slow!. Do not rush through this place, it is something you would want to take it slowly. Keep walking and munching, you will never feel tired here and in the 9 streets!
A perfect slice of canal life.. Just walk it. It's lovely and worth doing several times. Old buildings, a beautiful canal, cobble streets. Pretty girls on bikes. What's there not to like?

canal with lots of life. We're staying for 2 weeks in apartment in canal house on Prinsengracht. There are many shops, cafes, bars along the canal. It's an interesting place to walk, from one end to another, and we're enjoying looking out our windows at the boats, people, and life on the canal.
Prinsengracht - very attractive. The houses seem to come directly out of one of these very old children books - it is enjoyable to walk and look on Prinsengracht
Great Strolling Canal. Great galleries and small cafés on this canal...pick an afternoon and stroll away the day! Make sure to visit the Antique Shops to look for old Delft Blue Tiles!
Exellent. Exellent views, spring time, well maintained canals. Could sit and drink a beer for hours looking at canal views.
An Old Amsterdam Favourite. The Van Puffelen restaurant. Its an old sort of posh 'brown cafe' which offers good foood in a wonderful atmosphere.

A lovely walk to Anne Frank's House. Very grand canal among many lovely canals. I found myself here several times. The atmosphere was superb. As mentioned in the title Anne Frank's House is in the vicinity, and also the lovely Westerkirk.
Beautiful canal. Picturesque canal, interesting buildings and shops, restaurants but not at all over crowded. Could amble in peace exploring and watching the world go by.

Bustling but beautiful. Very pretty tree lined canal with many cafes, enjoyed my time walking along watching people ride their cycles and their boats along. The Anne Frank house is well worth the visit along this canal. Very easy to get around on trams.
want to live there. very intersting and busy place, always try to visit the area when im in amsterdam. fabulous shops and eating places the dutch are so friendly and helpful

Beautiful walk.. It is hard not to find interesting sights anywhere in Amsterdam, but the Prinsengracht is something special. There are interesting and beautiful properties everywhere and many charming places to indulge yourself in. The canal is also well decorated on the banks and quite colorful.
beautiful architecture. another way of discovering this particular city: by water. The Prinsengracht has beautiful building and stylish architeture: worth while.

Prinsengracht. Nice canal, especially near Ann Franck house, at the intersection with Leliegracht. One can visit the Houseboat Museum, the Tulip Museum, the West CHurch where Rembrandt is burried, Ann Franck House and at the end of the trip one certainly derevers a delicious but overpriced pancake form the Pancake Bakery :)
Beautiful Canal. This area is filled with small restaurants and shops. Wonderful experience , clean and tourist friendly. The trees and houseboats make for a great photo .

Prinsengracht (from Westerkerk - heading north to Haarlemerdijk > centraal station). Prinsengracht is a popular canal! This review covers Prinsengracht from the Westerkerk > Ann Frank House to Haarlemerdijk > Centraal Station). Houses along this way are nummbered 1 to 300. Part of Prinsengracht intersects Raadhuisstraat and Rozengracht where the Westerkerk landmark is and Anne Frank huis. If you go north towards Central Station you'll pass by or enter into popular areas such as the Jordaan; Westermarkt; Lijnbaanmarkt; Noodermarkt; Haarlemerdijk; Haarlemerstraat. If you are going to visit one specific site - such as the markets, perhaps 2 hours is ample enough. If you want to take in as mmuch as you can - better to mmake half a day or mmore out of it. There is so mmuch to see - the picturesque canal, buildings, and shops. At the end of Prinsengracht (just steps away from Haarlemerdijk) you'll see a cool old cannon fromm the Amsterdam Defence Line! Stay tuned for another review of Prinsengracht but in the southerly direction!!!isabelydancer00

The Prinsengracht is wonderful.... Apart from visiting the Tulip Museum and walking past the Anne Frank House (I did not enter, the queues were too long) and photographing the Westerkerk from every angle...I just enjoyed walking up and down the Prinsengracht and photograhping various buildings, houseboats and images of the canal. Jordaan in Amsterdam, like Montmartre in Paris and Dorsoduro in Venice is magic!!!
The BEST canal. This is really the prettiest canal - be sure to stop at the Cafe de Smalle and sit and have a snack right along the canal on a sunny day
Beautiful canals. Take the "Hop on, hop off" canal bus and see all the canals. the view if different from the water. They even look different at different times of the day.
What you come to Amsterdam for.... This is just so beautiful. Grand and yet not stand offish. When did we forget to build for eternity like here?
Architecture. Wonderful to walk along and look at all the different architectural styles.Unfortunately there a lot of old bikes thrown into the canal

Wonderful to walk along. Take 1-2 hours for an enjoyable walk along the Prinsengracht. The buildings are authentic and well maintained, the atmosphere is nice and people helpful if you have any question to ask.
Prettiest canal in Amsterdam. I wish I had visited here on the first day of my trip. Such a beautiful area with lot's of house boats and unique shops. I will stay in this area the next time I visit.

Breath taking views. We took a self guided walking tour of the "Golden Age" canals that run through the west side of Amsterdam. The Prinsengracht and Herengracht canals are very picturesque from the view point of the canal looking out or strolling the streets along the canals.

A peacefull walk. When the tempratures are right and when the sun comes out its even nicer. A beautyfull canal with bridges and houseboats. Some parts are more colorfull than others...
We thought it was worth the walk, so we walked it all the way and some of the way back... it was a sunny day ;)
walk the canals. This city is like a dream come true for someone who loves walking in cities. This canal and many others are full of unique and beautiful architecture. I just love it.

Best Canal. This was the prettiest of all the canals in Amsterdam with plenty of houseboats and beautiful canal houses lining it's banks. The bridges are great opportunities for photo shots. Worth seeking out!
A beautiful canal of Amsterdam. A beautiful canal located in the middle of Amsterdam and surrounding the inner circle of the city. The canal houses are impressive and the bridges simply beautiful.
Stayed here with a view. Our small hotel faced this canal. So scenic. Lovely area to walk and visit. Safe and interesting area to enjoy.

Shopping and dining options galore. This popular and beautiful canal makes up part of the fun '9 Streets' shopping area. Stores open at 10.30, so enjoy a lazy morning in your hotel or apartment before heading out to explore. The Ann Frank House always has long lines, but just down the street some great dining options abound.

Beautiful. You can just imagine the Dutch Golden Age merchants while walking down this street. Great hotels, tends to be more quiet, and a great jumping off point for the rest of the city. I did my masters degree here years ago and still constantly have dreams about living here when I am older.

A vision of the real Amsterdam. We stayed on a houseboat on this canal for a week. The houseboat was great and the canal itself is a "cultural highway." Evenings on the canal are very busy as boats take leisurely cruises along the canal. Great for people watching, not so great for sleeping. While we did not travel along the canal by boat, we did walk along the canal on several occasions. Amsterdam is not my favourite city in the world but the area around the canal provides a real contrast to the cultural wasteland around the train station and the red light district. Walk along the canal, look up to appreciate the buildings, tall and thin to maximize water frontage. Enjoy an afternoon meal, pastry, or drink along the canal. Find a street vendor selling Stroopwafel or herring. This is a much more relaxed part of Amsterdam. While I would not call it the best attraction in Amsterdam, I did find it to be the one place where I could appreciate the beauty of the city.

A beautifull canal indeed !. We just spent a few days in Amsterdam, and that canal is one of the most intersting, since it's circles the very old town. Plenty of nice views and plenty of stuff to discover and visit along it !

Would make a nice walk. With my limited time in Amsterdam, I decided to take a walk along one of the canal and enjoy the beauties of the city. A search in Tripadvisor led me to this canal. I felt that this canal was the same as the other two main canal. The architecture of buildings along the canal is very picturesque. All the houses have 3-4 floors and their façade is different from another one. Everything looks miniature like. The houseboats are another interesting feature of Amsterdam canals. There are lots of cafes along the canal and make sure to sit back and relax and sip a cup of coffee while watching people biking around. The best way to explore the city is by bike or canal cruises. Don’t miss them.
Postcard Perfect. Our hotel (Pultizer) was on this street. It is lovely. Best to walk and wander until you get so tire you have to visit a cafe for coffee, tea (or beer) and a pastry.
Average. Average view as all the canals, houses, etc all look the same after a while, we ended up here looking for the temporary location of the Van Gogh museum
Beautiful canal and spectacular houses.. Just lovely,wandering up canal,especially by night with bridges lit up.Just watch out for bikes with no lights.

the most beautiful canal in Amsterdam, the XXX city. to visit, to sail upon, to eat, to market ... there are so many good places on Prinsengracht and among them 42 Korte Prinsengracht and Pepper and Salt® Events Amsterdam
No big thing. This is just another area where visitors and residents gather and enjoy themselves, but it is not exactly something to go out of your way to see.

A popular canal to walk around. The Prinsengracht is a large and popular canal. It features lots of shops, restaurants, and cafes. It is a fun place to walk around and will help orientate you as you walk around Amsterdam.
Canals of Amsterdam. Boat trip is great. At night the hotels look wonderful. You also have a unique view of this brilliant city,
Very pretty. Great canal, perfect on a crisp sunny winter's day - plenty of places to eat, drink and smoke as well as simply chill out and enjoy the view.
Beautiful. My fiancé and I took a boat tour that went through the canal here and it was just breathtaking. I recommend for everyone to take a boat tour through the canals of Amsterdam.
Worth a visit. It is just amazing to walk along the cannal. The cute houses and everything. I would visit again soon.

What place to be!. My wife & I stayed in a apartment on the Prinsengracht and we had all week long to stroll arm in amr up and down this canal during the morning, noon and night. It was breathtaking to say the least and our connection to the city via trams was not more than 30 yards from our door step. We went in March 2013 and it was quiet but very sedate. I can't imagine what this area is like in the middle of the summer.

Canal Trip. Nobody should go the Amsterdam without going on at least one of the Canal trips on Offer. It is a wonderful way of seeing Amsterdam. We got a day pass for the Canal Bus. You can then get on and off the canal boat throughout the day and jump back on any of the three routes - which cover the three different canals. there is a commentary running on board so that you learn all about the canals as you go round. Very relaxing too!

The view. This was our first time in Amsterdam so we could certainly not miss out seeing the great canals. We first took a tour boat and then we wallked the canal. The guide on the tour boat was very knowledgable and fun so we got to learn a lot about its history. Then we walked the canal to better appreciate the architecture and the vibe of Amsterdam. You can easily walk for hours and hours.
Beautiful. Wonderful view of the canals, an area that I would say is much less busier to walk around than ones close to damrak. Wrap up warm!

Lush walk with boats and building to photgraph. A walk along Prinsengracht is great for visitors and tourists and is perfect for great photo opportunities. Lots of interesting looking boats on the canal and great doorways and buildings along the way. In Feb dress warmly and definitely take a camera anytime of the year. Spent New Year in Amsterdam in 2012 and saw parts of the canal completely frozen over. Good shops and cafes along the way too.
Walked from Museumplein to the Ann Frank House. Great walking Canal.Found a great old Record shop and a few real good Coffeeshops as well.Wear good walking shoes and watch out for the bikes.
Lovely walk along this canal. Explore this canal and it's great historyCool Architecture, some lovely cafes, and quirky shops!!!!!!
Nice background for photos. This is a beautiful area particularly when it's bright and sunny. There are many good spots for pictures. Nice atmosphere for walking.

Lovely area. We stayed at the Petit Prince and would really recommend it as it overlooks the canal and there is lots going on. It is lovely around dusk to watch the streets change when you are sitting next to the fire with a glass of wine and the candles glowing. Area is great.
Prinsengracht is beautiful. This is as good as other travelers have reviewed for a historical walk and enjoying a drink soaking in history and the local culture.

Vintage shops, etc. Around the Nine Streets, very elegant shops + atmospheric bars. Wander around and make sure you visit the street just off Prinsengracht - lovely ethnic + Balinese leather bag shop called Margreth Mackenzie - fab stuff run by lovely lady.

Beautiful. Beautiful, not to be missed area of Amsterdam. We first saw it from a canal boat and then when we returned a few days later to visit the Anne Frank House. It was beautiful on a cold, sunny day in february but I'm sure it is even more beautiful in the spring or summer. Definitely worth a visit!

Strolling through the canals. This street is just lovely. The great canal lying beside and the beautiful shops make it extremely pleasant to stroll around the area. Furthermore, the Joordan district, where I was staying, is very pretty and it's worth to visit.

Even fabulous in a rain and cold. This is a beautiful area and I am sure it is heavenly in the spring and summer, as we were there at the start of January and I had the flu, it was merely fabulous. The boats tied up along the canal sides are so interesting and a delight to behold and get a few photographs off. Then there are so many different little boutique shops and cafes as well, you could spend a good day wandering around, an utter delight and free to boot.In the evening the whole area lights up with delightful bulbs highlighting the bridge arches and the entrances to some streets, just lovely. The area is full of many age groups and people walking their small dogs - it really does make you want to pack up and move there.

Prinsengracht market. Love this market. Not so much for the tourist as the flea market at Waterlooplein. Lots of organic foods, cheese, breads, and a lovely little stall selling Poffertjes at the end.

Anne Frank's House. Best to book your ticket in advance and save waiting in the lines outside. Highly recommend the presentation in your chosen language as this gives an interesting insight into what you're about to see. Relax and reflect after the museum in the clean friendly coffee shop
Typical Amsterdam. Beautiful architecture, great atmospere and nice alleys in between with nice and different shops and restaurants.

Romantic area. We had a very nice and romantic walk in this area. It reminds a bit Venice but only cause of canals. Great place with nice stores and a lot of thing to photograph if you are big fan of photography like me.

Great Area for Romantic Walks. The area is just beautiful. There are stunning little boutique stores to browse through and in the evenings, it lights up! We spent more than 1 evening meandering through the streets
lovely area. Pleasant to walk around, very pretty nice shops good views and plenty of photo opportunities. The river is nice and some good places to eat

This is what makes this city original. Amsterdam is the Venice of the north. These canals really make this city an original place to visit. You really can't avoid them when you visit this city. They are awesome landmarks that are perfect fo picture taking. The unique arch shape of the city and unorthodox layout built around the canals made me want to come back and revisit and re-explore this city.
Nice way to spend the afternoon. We had a nice time just walking around and looking at the beautiful houses and architecture. We enjoyed going inside cafe's and stores discovering wonderful treats.
Beautiful.. Very relaxing and picturesque area to walk in, if you keep an eye out for the bicycles. It's easy to navigate the area using the canals as a guide.
Authentic Amsterdam. Nice to walk down here away from the busy tourist spots.Wonderful buildings all along the canal to appreciate.Some nice shops, bars to discover as well.
great walk. nice scenery to enjoy a afternoon city walk. Not crowded with tourists at all and try to discover a hidden bar to enjoy the local set up and drink-suggestions.

Charming canal, a delight to walk along. The Prinsengracht is a pretty nice canal with some places worth visiting that the Anne Frank Huis and the Tulip museum. It is a nice canal to take a boat ride too or just walk along from end to end. The old Dutch houses long the way are also a treat for the eyes, like along any other canal. Very Nice!!!
My fave stroll. I can't really say, other than not so bustly as some of the commercially streets and nice to walk by th canal with a few nice individual restaurants and shops, not so tacky!!!
Charm....!. To walk along the canal and look at the architecture and charm of the old canal houses... wonderful!

We liked this canal the most..... By the time you get to Prinsengracht, the majority of the tourists have disappeared, even though it is only a short walk away from the centre.We liked this area the most as there were numerous little bars restaurants and shops dotted around. It felt very quaint, very serene and very Dutch. I'd highly recommend wondering around this area and getting a feel for the real Amsterdam.
A beautiful canal...lots of cute places. Walking (or boating) along the canals is the best way to experience Amsterdam. Prinsengracht is at the heart of it all.
Amsterdam at its best. Wonderful buildings, beautiful facades and all you expect to see here.House boats everywhere. Interesting to look at.
very nice to see the tipical dutch canal landscape. Very nice canal, with the house boats, very good to have a pleasant walk and see the tipical dutch houses. Anne Frank House is here.
So much to see. This is beautiful to walk along or to see the houses from the water. Must do, when in AMS as a tourist.
Canal area. The canal area has such a great, laid back feel. Very easy and pleasant walking and cycling. Delicious cake shops and coffee shops (both kinds...!) everywhere.

Beautiful canal. This canal area is one of the best in Amsterdam and is definitely worth checking out! There are lots of cafes and restaurants facing right onto the canal. In good weather, this is a particularly nice place to visit.
what can I say?. Hotel Pulitzer is on this street, which is an excellent location. Just a far enough walk away from the main "buzz".

nice shopping and restaurants + market area. This is a great canal with many trendy shops and while approaching from the North West side (Noordermarkt) you can find interesting markets on Saturday and Monday.Good restaurants all over the canal and nice cafe's.Be prepared to make a half hour walk before returning to the real heart of Amsterdam.
Charmed. By the scenery. By the variety of shops and small pubs. By the people .By the sphere.Amsterdam it its best.

Great cafes, restaurants and sites of interest. Slightly more sophisticated than the city centre with some nice bars and restaurants, (including catering for vegetarians- De Bolhoed recommended) and some picturesque houses. Anne Frank House and Prozenboot, (boat housing stray cats) both located here which indicates the eclectic nature of this canal!

Favourite canal, picturesque with charming streets off it. I think the Prinsengracht has to be my favourite canal. It was so pretty, with loads of interesting boutiques and cafes off it. I recommend the pancakes cafe 'Pancakes!' - there's not many tables so you might find that it's full when you get there, but if you do get it, it's a lovely, bright place with lots of tasty fare.

The most vibrant main canal of Amsterdam. I especially love this canal because its the most vibrant one. Gaypride canal Parade takes place here and so do many other different kinds of popular cultural events such as the Prinsengrachtconcert and sightseeing activities like Anne Frank huis, Westerkerk and Noordermarkt. The last mentioned, has a very lovely organic foodmarket on saturdays and on mondaynornings there is a second hand/antiques flea market which is really worth visiting because of the little gems you might just bump into totally unexpected :-) But then again, the best buys are always the ones you didnt look for anyways!

The best canal.. Our hotel, The Wiechmann is located on this canal, so we really lucked out. This is where you see most of the house boats and it is just so pleasant to walk or just sit at your window and people watch. This canal can connect you with many of the sites you will want to see.

Beautiful Canal Ring. Take a walk along this canal. If you go far enough, you can walk to the Anne Frankhuis. This canal stretch was really one of my favourites to walk around. It is pretty quiet and the architecture is amazing. Take a look.

Great introduction to Amsterdam. The best way to get a good introduction to Amsterdam is to go on a boat trip. Canal Bus is one of the operators plying the canals and their boats are convenient to hop on/hop off at various places along teh Prinsengracht. This is a major canal in Amsterdam and gives the first time or long time visitor wonderful views of Amsterdam's architecture and daily life. Recommended.

Root canal. When you go to Amsterdam a canal boat tour is a must, you have a view of the magnificent homes that line the canal from a unique perspective. Make sure to hang onto your daisy when the boat navigates the tight tunnels.

Beautiful district. Very nice and quite calm district near the centre of Amstedam. Cozy streets and canals - it definitely has its unique atmosphere. Also nice for a walk when it's dark - the lights look really nice, and the streets are quite empty in the evening.

Strawl around, find a cafe, enjoy. I always find it nice to strawl around Amsterdam...watch the scenery on the canals, boats passing by, houseboats, cyclers....just strawl around and catch the athmosphere

Inspiring canal. Been living on this canal for almost two years, and it is amazing how the tranquil water and the lazy boats can make your day. Strolling along the canal it is an intimate experience with the city.

Lovely walk. Just love walking on this street. Stop in a Winkels for apple pie if you are at that end. There is not a load of coffeeshops but the ones that are there are better than the city centre ones.

Great View!. We stayed on this street, and the view of the canal is extraordinary! The streets are simply charming! The area is gorgeous, and it is very centrally located, as well as in close proximity to public transportation.

Cool area, cool vibe. Prinsengracht is a place for young and up to date young adults who loves enjoying the scene of beautiful canals, combine with nice shopping experience and some cool local coffee house and pattiseries

Another lovely area of amsterdam. Another really scenic, beautiful area of amsterdam. It can all blur together the city is that beautiful. Brilliant to sit outside a brown cafe, sipping a westmalle triple and watching the world go by

A lovely stroll. We stayed in Hotel Le Boheme on the Leidesplein and walked along the Prisengracht to get to Anne Frankhuis. The walk was beautiful along the canal, with impressive houses, quirky houseboats and unique shops and cafes.
Boat ride. Pretty good. We went around on one of those canal boats and took photos and all that ... Cannot think of any more to add
very nice. we had lunch on one of these boats. it was very nice and we enjoyed it. Unfortunately it was raining.
Great place to stroll. I love walking along Prinsengracht, popping into the many "brown cafes" along the way, having a drink along the canal, and exploring the mane side canals.
An interesting walk or boat ride.. Very interesting to walk along the canal especially when out of the central tourist area. A good view of lovely old Dutch town homes in real neighborhood.
unique. the cyclists' priority, the cobbles, the architecture, the bars, the Dutch, the service, the shops, the cafes and the cyclists!

Crazy about the charm of Amsterdam city. I love the canals of the city, and just love the atmosphere in the city.
All the beautiful buildings and romantic canals in Amsterdam is really gorgeous and worth a visit.
Alle 4 canals in the city is all very lovely and special.
Excellent shopping. Must visit this place. Hand-crafted bags and pottery are excellent. Do not shop from museums, though. Very expensive.
Beautiful. Beautiful walk along a historic canal. Be sure to walk on both sides of the canal to get a correct impression of the area
Lots to see, many photo ops!. Such a beautiful area to walk around, boat, or tram the area. Many coffee shops, and small places to grab a bite or sit down an relax.
unique. The area is unique, cosy, vibrant, urban, and historic. Great place to walk. Watch out for the bicycles. The canal is also very picturesque - house boats, barges, personal little boats..
Simply Beautiful to walk around. This is in the centre and the walk along the canal is hard to beat. Lots to do & see. Visit Anne Frank's House.

Trendy. A trendy district close to both the Leidesplein and surrounded by beautiful canals. Trendy boutique stores and restaurants surround the Prinsengracht and it is easily accessible by tram. This tends to be a busy area in Amsterdam with plenty of shoppers about.
Upscale neighborhood. A upscale neighborhood with small pubs, cafes, parks and nannies walking kids and dogs. A slice of upper middle class life.
Beautiful at night. Lots of restaurants and shops in this gracht. Best to get around at night since roads in this canal is quite busy at noon.

Action Central. Best place for a beer and impromptu concerts, etc...
Excellent restaurants all within a short walk.
So much to see and do - at any hour !
An attractive canal. This canal has plenty to see and eat (!) along its length. Several guide web sites include walking tours of this canal and make the buildings come alive. Worth wandering along
You must make a boat tour at the Prinsengracht. I had already several times a tour with the boat tour company LOVERS. I always enjoyed it. The best woud be in during the night. It is very romantic.

Walking in the autumn. Autumn is perfect and real here. You should walk along the canal and watching trees in the autumn. This walking route is not very touristy-not very crowded and ideal for living real Amsterdam soul.
Nice view and experience. Walked and sailed through the canal on a sunny day. Beautiful scenery and places that must be visited.
ann frank. second visit here and well worth the money. Haunting and emotional experience. Should be on everyone's must see list.

West side of Canal Joordan. The streets from Elandsgracht to Brouwersgracht were my favourite very much like the Greenwich Village of New York except in Amsterdam, olde world, pubs, canal houses, sleek designer shops, bakeries, cafes, antquie shops
Wonderful canal walk. The hotel where I stayed (ITC) was on this canal. It's a lovely walk along that canal as well as the other two nearby.

Stopped here. Our apartrment was on Prinsengracht which had plenty going on within a couple of minutes walk and a tram stop about 80 yards away.An excellent location for anything that you wanted to do in Amsterdam.A very pleasant area to while away the time either strolling on the canal or having a drink at the numerous cafes

A special canal amongst canals. This is just one of many canals that run sort of in a semi circle in the centrum of Amsterdam. It spans different neighborhoods, probably the most famous being the Jordaan. The Anne Frank Huis is on one bank as is the nearby famous Pancake Bakery.
Nice area. Just take a walk around the canals and enjoy. Pop in to a shop, take a coffee at a cafe, in june its lovely
Lovely Canal. We spent a day just walking along the different canals. We couldn't stop taking pictures along the way. What an enjoyable way to experience Amsterdam!

Great way to see Amsterdam. The view of the various architectural styles of Amsterdam, the bustling shopping streets and a glimpse into the everyday life in Amsterdam. One of the best ways to see a part of the city

best place to be!. Always visit the canals when in Amsterdam. Prinsengracht is one of the longest and one of the nicest canals there are.. take a Rondvaartboat or better, find friends with a little boat! You'll love it!

Can't miss it. Each time we visit A'dam we end up in this picturesque street, it's simply beautiful and really typical for this most wonderful city. We totally love this place. We looked into buying a little house in the Prinsengracht but €2,000,000 is a tad over budget for us ^_^
Beautiful and relaxing!. This is a must do when in Amsterdam, nice to relax and go around the canals. Have your camera ready!
nice central street. no matter if u want u ll definately cross this street that leads you from leidse plein to keizergracht where the shopping street is.

Herengracht, Keizersgracht and Prinsengracht are a must-see!. The center of Amsterdam might be a touristic heaven, but I really loved the 3 "main" canals (Prinsengracht is the outer one). They also have quite a few shops (especially in the "9 Streets"), lovely architecture and nice little canals in between.When you take a walk at Prinsengracht, make sure you eat some pancakes at the Pancake Bakery. Also, the Jordaan is just behind Prinsengracht.

nice walking. Walking along canals is always nice in Amsterdam. This has quite few impressive building, and also really good restaurant facing on the water. So, you can enjoy it the day and the evening!

Wonderful stroll. The first thing we did after arriving at our hotel from the airport was to dump our bags and take a walk along the Prinsengracht from Leidesplein to the Anne Frank House. The tallest church spire in Amsterdam at Westerkerk sits right on the canal overshadowing the Anne Frank House.What a beautiful and vibrant area with many interesting features. The canal boats silently ply the waterway while the houseboats (including a Houseboat Museum) are a unique, attractive and enviable way to live in the city. A myriad of small shops, cafes and other businesses are ripe for exploration and patronage.Do yourself a favor and view the length of the canal by foot or canal boat tour for a fascinating way to see the canal and city.
Great area. Loads to see, just wandered around taking it all in. Loads of choice in cafes and restraurants, shops, picturesque. One of my favourite areas.
Well chosen name. Walking in Amsterdam demands a lot a attention. Cars, bikes and trams drive in narrow streets and bicycle drivers are fearless. Beware !

Lovely!!. Took a river cruise and enjoyed the lovely tree-lined canal with beautiful houses lining it. One can also the Noordermarket(Northern Market) along the canal. Nearby is the Northern Church. The Western Church along this beautiful canal has a tall spire with a crown at the top.

Beautiful canal. This is such a beautiful tree lined canal/street. It was very quiet and the buildings were nice to see. Accordingly this was where the rich used to live. I would definately recommend have a walk along Prinsengracht, very romantic and scenic.

Worth a walk along this canal. This, and the two adjoining canals are worth walking down particularly on a sunny day. For those with history bent, it is worth going to the Amsterdam Museum to learn their construction and use. The ex-warehouses now apartments make a good street frontage. Moreover there's some great cafes along the canal to sit in the sunshine and soak up the ambience and beverages.
Lovely canal to Walk. Just a lovely canal to walk, much more peaceful than the center in the evening with many shops and great little atmospheric restaurants. Love it.

Walk, sit, admire.. Our hotel was on Prinsengracht, lovely area, great houses, good cafes, good strolling territory, excellent people watching, not too many bikes [!], quiet and peaceful. A fantastic difference from the centre.
Great walk. Loved the atmosphere and enjoyed the exercise. Fun to see how they live and work, great eating places

Messing about on the canal. Enjoy the soaring canalside houses and the many independent boutiques in this area. Loads of places to stop and admire the view, nosey into the houseboats and admire the local passion for all things bike!

A Good Place to Rent a Canal Boat. In September 2012 we rented a canal boat for four nights on the Peinsengracht. It was fun to sit out the balcony and wave to tourists on the tour boats. It was amazing the number of boats that would go by in the evening. The canal was a little dirty with some floating debris but a great way to experience Amsterdam.

Beautiful - soak it all up. The primsengracht canal has some stunning features. Although one of Amsterdam's principal tourist attractions is situated along the banks of this canal it remains distinctly quiet and tranquil. It's lovely just to walk or even take a boat along the canal and just take in the beautiful architecture including th stunning Westerkerk.
lovely. took a canal boat ride. Not sure if it went down prinsengracht, but would recommend the trip to anybody for a view of amsterdam from the canals.
Great Architecture. Along one of the many strands of canals in Amsterdam, the Prinsengracht features homes with lovely facades along a tree-lined canal.

Prinsengracht. Stop, sit and relax. Stop, Sit and relax. Take a moment spend 15 minutes at least to just watch the world go by. The Prinsengracht is one of the most stunning canals to view. This is what Amsterdam is all about. Just remember to take time out when travelling from one place to another to stop and take in the atmosphere. For one its free what can be better !!!!!
like on postcards. The Herengracht looks in reality exactly the way it looks on pastcards: simply great ! Nice to do an early morning walk along the water when Amsterdam is awakening.
great spot for pictures, upscale and quiet. great spot for pictures, upscale and quiet. Pulitzer hotel was excellent and resturants nearby are good.

Beautiful canal. We actually stayed on the Prinsengracht in a house boat (The Prinsen Boat). What a great experience and unique way to enjoy Amsterdam. The area we were in was beautiful and quite within an easy walking distance to many shops, restaurants and sites.
canal cruise. the canal cruise takes you around several canals and you see the beautiful architectures of the houses on the canals and the outlay of the city.

Great to wander or cycle. I spent quite a bit of time wandering and cycling up and down Prisengracht - it's a cute canal that rings the oldest part of the city with cafés, bars and restaurants on a number of corners. You can also wander from here up into the old town, through the "Nine Streets" or across into Jordaan.

strolling in Amsterdam. I love walking all around Amsterdam. It is such a walking friendly city (except that Bicycles reign and walkers are second class cititzens). The area is lovly, the houses so unique.

An Enjoyable Experience Along The Canal.. Prinsengracht Street in Amsterdam in the Netherlands is a quiet neighborhood that runs in line with one of the canals. The historic house is located on this street. It is quite typical of Amsterdam. You can watch the boats navigate this very narrow canal as well as spending time talking with the cities residents. BE SURE TO WATCH OUT FOR THE BICYCLES! There are a few l coffee Hauses
Beautiful Canal. Make sure it's part of your walking tour of the canal rings. The Anne Frank House is on the this street.

One of the most lovely and liveable canals in Amsterdam.. Having lived in Amsterdam from my birth and lived at the Prinsengracht for over 15 years I know how unique this canal is for visitors.First of all it is the longest of all Amsterdam Canals. But is it is also the canal which is the canal to live at.The diversity of the houses is enormous and the shopping for locals and visitors is very divers.One should try to walk or bike the canal.
Chill out haven. Lovely to walk along and people watch and look at the great buildings. Great cafes and restaurants along the way. You can hire boats to ride on.
lovely canal. Such a pretty canal with lots of interest along the length of it, including some lovely cafes. Fantastic Veggie restaurant at number 60 is definitely worth a look!
Unique and late medieval. An excellent example of the many miles of canals. The whole city has many charming and unique spots along the canals, at city center, and in teh museum area.

Scenic plus. Beautiful waterway which wraps around the city. Go local - just get on a bike and explore it, you won't be disappointed. Just keep your wits about you: trams, cars, bikes and pedestrians make for potentially busy intersections.

Water water everywhere. Took an eco boat trip along the canals, with an interesting guide and because it was a small boat with a maximum of 12 people we felt more able to ask questions. Well worth a trip on the water which is what Amsterdam is all about.

No, not all the canals look the same.... There are lots of canals actually looking exactly the same, it is hard to distinguish one from other. But while you are wandering around; which I believe is one of the best things you can do in Amsterdam; and once you feel something is different around you; and think that "this canal is somehow different than all the other with all its houses, shops & brown cafés", that means you are definitely in Prinsengracht. At this very point, I would like to indicate that, one of the most meaningful museums in the world, the Anne Frankhuis, is also located at that very canal. As my final remarks, go there early in the morning, go there during the sunset and also go there during the night.

nice area to take a strawl its part of three grachts. the heerengracht the prinsen and the kaizersgracht nice cafes also by hop on hop off available they call it the nine streets also have a look at the singel street esp towards dam square side area
Canal Visit. Like all the canals in central Amsterdam, this one is a must. When you visit Amsterdam, a canal boat cruise is a must do acitivity as it provides a wonderful overview of the city.

Beautiful canal - great to walk on and take in the essence of the city!. Wonderful picturesque canal alongside many coffee shops, restaurant and shops. Take a stroll down the canal by foot, by pedicab or by boat. Absolutely beautiful. Watch out for those cyclists though! They are everywhere and they really don't stop for anything!
We were there!. How could we miss it: Hotel 717 opened straight onto the quai. Nice for strolling and enjoying the lights (oh, and dodging the bikes!)
Lovely. Lovely to stroll along . We walked from Leidesplein to Ann Frank house and back. Very pretty. We took many pictures. Be careful of the cyclists they are lethal lol.

Beautiful Canal with shops, cafes, restaurants. Our hotel room faced the canal where we saw many small boats floating by. In walking distance were many shops, galleries and cafes, especially in the Nine Little Streets. If you prefer a less busy, small shop atmosphere, you will love strolling on Prisengracht
Take a canal boat. We took a paddle boat and spent the day on the canal. Looking at the architecture and enjoying the scene. A wonderful, upscale area, full of great restaurants and shops.
Very Beautiful on this Canal. Picture postcard Perfect Prinsengracht! Beautiful walk along this canal with lots of history and breathtaking views along the canal by foot or on a cruise.

Perfect canal walk. Everyday during our stay in Amsterdam we walked along Prisengracht as we stayed at the Pulitzer Hotel. We ate dinner two nights at restaurants along here- I cannot remember their names but one was very chic and foodie and the other very local and casual. We loved looking in the windows of the art galleries and coffee houses along the way and watching the boat traffic go by. The sidewalks are narrow and the cars and bikes zoom by! There is a fun gift store just down the street from the Pulitzer with kooky gifts, papergoods and fun trinkets. We walked to the Anne Frank House early one morning to get in line for the 9am opening-there is a coffee house with bagels next door and the line starts at 8am. Well worth it as we were able to walk through the house and museum without large crowds.

Beautiful, bohemian, the jewel of Amsterdam.. Nothing beats a long, slow walk around Prinzengracht on a sunny summer's evening. The canal is (in my opinion) the most beautiful of the many canals present in the city. So many coffeeshops, arthouses, pretty bridges and cyclists. A trip to Amsterdam is incomplete without experiencing Prinzengracht.
Take a boat tour. The best way to see Prinsengracht is from inside of it. Take any of the gised tour and enjoy. After, go to one of the many Cafes on the side and enjoy the view. it's amazing!
Not to be missed. Accessible. This is not to be missed. It is unique and special. I recommend that you make time for it.

Canal tour - another must see of Amsterdam. If you reach Amsterdam, take a canal tour to get a first glimps of the city. Prinsengracht is probably the most spectacular. You might not notice when you enter another canal, and can miss some attaractions on the sides, that's why a guided tour is recommended.

Make time for a stroll on a quiet Sunday morning - you won't regret it!. Prinsengracht is one of the old large grachten that surround the old city of Amsterdam. It is well worth strolling along the waterside, checking out the old buildings there, enjoying time in a café, watching the tourist boats pass by every now and then and more. Sunday mornings are especially good, as the whole city seems quieter these hours.
Pretty canal scene. Lovely cafe's, sit and watch boats going by with cold beer! Nice shops nearby to meander, this is the Amsterdam I came to see, quiet, clean, relaxing.
Beautiful!. This and the other two canals of Amsterdam give the city something different and interesting that you will not find in most other cities.
Fun to watch!. This is one of the more crowded canals but fun to watch all the various boats cruise through on the weekends, sometimes 2-3 thick as they go by.

Great area to visit. Beautiful canals, homes and buildings. Great restaurants and shops. Must see in Amsterdam. Anne Frank museum located on Prinsengracht canal. Close to Van Gogh Museum, Flower market, Rembrandt Museum, Rijkmuseum, etc.
Pancake Bakery. Fantastic soup and pancakes very filling - Nice coffee & staff were really nice. Just past the Anne frank house - one not to be missed

Canal Ride is a must in Amsterdam. A canal ride is the best way to see the city. We did the Museum Tour. We got on in front of the Rijksmuseum and it did a full loop of the city to have us back in 1.5 hours. Great views.

Prettiest canal. Walk, bike or sail through here, it will give you a full experience of the city. Lot's of restaurants, cafe's, bar, etc on here. Takes you from great shopping on Haarlemmerdijk, through Noordermarkt, Jewish corner, crossing leidsestreet all the way up to Utrechtse street. All great places to visit.
Gay Pride Boat Parade 2012. Fantastic! I've been in Amsterdam for four Prides, seen four parades and this year's was by far the best :)

Quaint area. Quiet, quaint area to stroll. Full of sidewalk and canal-side cafes. Beautiful, old buildings. The calmness is a nice change after the hustle and bustle of Dam Square and Central Amsterdam.

Boat tour along Prisengracht. The best way to fully appreciate Prinsengracht is taking a boat tour that rides alongside its extension. Fron the boat you will see all the architecture and different buildings besides having a guide to explain everything.

Worth the reviews. Fussy foodie Londoner went to Vlamming, good review shocker!!!, Actually, secluded, mostly residential street,hosts charming intimate restaurant for all ages. Couples, families groups, all welcome. No children's menus of niggets and chips, so no fussy fussy eaters. Worth the walk, charming, sophisticated, good valie, but informal, do try it.

Beautiful on foot, boat or bicycle!. This is a beautiful area and street. Anne Frank's house is on this street. It's great just walking along the street and canals in the area. I really love the architecture of all the houses and flats here in the area (and Amsterdam in general). It's interesting staying in a rental apartment in the area the set up on the inside of these houses. The long steep walk to the top of the flats is interesting.Some say the best way to see the area is by boat and I definitely think you need to explore Amsterdam by boat but I also enjoy aimlessly walking around the various neighborhoods. It's a gorgeous place in the summer. Last week has been the busiest I've ever seen Amsterdam. It was the Gay Pride Amsterdam celebration this past weekend and I've never seen anything quite like it.... very festive and great atmosphere. Definitely take the time to walk around Prinsengracht. Gorgeous area.

Beautiful Canal and Area. Our family experienced this area on the Blue Boat Tour and while walking around before doing the Anne Frank Tour. It provides a nice look into some of the old world Dutch architecture and landscapes as you stroll through. This is an area where families can leisurely enjoy Amsterdam without so much touristy stuff. Definitely a place to visit while here due to its unique and quaint environments and picture opportunities.

good views of the city. Not as scenic as some city canal trips i've been on but well worth a visit while in Amsterdam. Unlike some reviewers would recommend planning a visit while there as it certainly gives you a different perspective on this fascinating city.
what a great street/canal. we stayed at the wonderful Amsterdam Wiechmann Hotel, loved it. Walked to Anne Frank Huis, town, Historical Musem, canals, boutiques.
Merchant land. Wonderful old houses, beautiful and typically Dutch spanning the last 200 years. Must do a canal tour on this part to really enjoy sthe true spirit of Amsterdam
Standard. Not exactly amazing but it's nice to have something like this in the middle of a city. I wouldn't allocate time to go and see this as your bound to pass it walking through Amsterdam.
Alook back in history. A look back in history of old Amsterdam just take a stroll around the area some beautiful buildings close to local tram stops and some nice coffee shops

Wonderful in summer!. All the main canal areas are a pleasure to walk, or boat, along when the weather is good. The Prinsengracht in summer is lively, with lot's of sidewalk cafes, people and bicycles in the streets, boats on the canal, and sights like the Anne Frank Museum.
Beautiful canals. The canal houses are just fascinating and the canals themselves are so pretty. Many house boats with flowers and plants.

Fascinating canalside experience. Avoid the characterless burger bars and pizza shops of Damrak and explore the true beauty of Amsterdam. A delightful walk around Prinsengracht should be on any itinerary.

Beautiful walk. It is so much fun to see the local canal boat dwellers out on the weekend. You also see people celebrating showers and birthdays in the boats going by. Try to visit a Hofje on Prinsengracht 89-133 or 159-171, open 10-6 on weekdays.
Lovely. Amsterdam's canals are the main place to see there. If you can take a boat to see them, the best it is.
Nice piece of A'dam. Took a stroll on the Prinsengracht, enjoyed the view, had dinner at the Vlaming which was great and visited the Anne Frank House
What a lovely canal and street. All kinds of restaurants and some fun design-y shops. Anne Frank House is here as well, and that is definitely worthwhile
don't miss the canal tour. you can view the city from a differnt angle. you get a vocal explanation but also funny remarks from the captain
A nice area with interesting museum and nice restaurant. I went here to visit the Anne Frank museum and to have dinner at the Pancake Bakery. A nice area along the canal. Really nice houses
Beautiful. Took a walk this area! Walk a lovely area, very relaxing and great for photo opportunities! I reccomend you see this if you visit Amsterdam.
Enjoyed Canal Trip. Amsterdam's history is told by its canals, so be sure you take the canal trip as it's not only interesting but good for orienting oneself;

Love walking along the canals.... Be sure to go early in the morning when everything is nice and quite and the canal calm. I took lots of reflection photos of houses and bridges in the canal.
A must see!

Favorite Canal in Amsterdam. This is perhaps the loveliest canal in Amsterdam. Peaceful, quiet and beautiful. There are very neat bicycle seats at the end of each intersection where you can sit and watch the swans floating around. It's lined with cute cafes where you can have your koffie and watch the world go by. The homes are also particularly beautiful and interesting.

Prinsengracht 508. We rented from Marcelle and couldn't have been a better arrangement. 3rd floor, large apartment,,modern kitchen, all the amenities to cook and serve GREAT food at home. So close to everything we wanted to do .. Museums ... Deli's, wine shops, cheeses, superb baguettes just around the corner! If you find this,place available take it .... Even has a choice of two coffee shops just a block away!

Must be part of any boat ride. Don't miss out on this and any other canal you can get a boat ride through. This is truly Amsterdam's beauty, if you're lucky enough to be in the city during some great summer weather you'll definitely enjoy your time.
perfect. very good place to see it .The people from amsterdam are so friendly.The place itself is so good only the transport is a little bit expensive.You van enjoy your trip as it is safety.

Lovely canal with the best tea shop!. This canal is very lovely, a little overly touristy with places like the Anne Frank House, the Cheese Museum and the Tulip Museum on it, but the building are gorgeous and there are some great pubs and restaurants. There is also a great tea shop - the Simon Levelt tea and coffee store. Try their 'The Wonders of Amsterdam' tea - so delicious! Definitely worth a stroll around when you are in the city.

Favourite canal. Prinsengracht is the prettiest and most interesting canal to wander along, stretching from the Jordaan to the Red Light District. Westerkerk, Anne Frank House,canal tours and brilliant restaurants can all be found within this area. Enjoy a stroll through all that Amsterdam has to offer just by wandering from one end of this canal to the other.
Stunning. Canals in Amsterdam are what makes that city unique. Reflections of buildings on the water, little boats, inhabited barges... lovely!

stayed in canal house. Loved the street because it was in close proximity to all the attractions and yet it was far enough away from the crowds/safe neighborhood/cafe /shopping/ noordermarkt great farmers market
Great place to visit. Great place to get away from the busier sections of town
busy, lovely, area of the Dam.. loved people watching here - both on the canal and sidewalks. But didn't like all the road works and dangerous man holes and very uneven pavements.

Lovely Area. Beautiful area of Amsterdam.
Lots to do and see here.

The actual heart of the city. Goes all through the city. Has a certain vibe that makes it unique.
A must see when you are in town and if possible on a boat
Family Holiday. Nice architecture and nice atmosphere. Old part of Amsterdam with lots of history and character.
beautiful area. The area around this canal is very picturesque and vibrant. There are many good restaurants with outdoor dining. This is a good place to walk and experience Amsterdam.
Must See. This is the street on which the Anne Frank House is located and other beautiful canal houses

Seventeenth Century Splendor. Be sure to look for the house Peter the Great rented while he stayed in the Netherlands to learn the art if ship building. He stayed mostly in Zaandam, and his courtiers near destroyed the Amsterdam house.

A great street to stroll. We loved this street - don't miss the Anitek store - it's a gem filled with lovely antiques. You may get a chance to look at some unusual items and offer your opinion on what they are - there's a strange helmet and a vacuum tube-like object waiting to be identified. Ask the owner to see them. Have fun!

Best route. One of the best routes to get from the Amstel to Central Station, if you have time. You will find on your way the main interesting points of the city: Utrechtsestraat, Leidsestraat, Jordaan and gables of all kind.
One of the many lovely canals. Stayed near this canal, strolling along this canal is very nice.

good atmosphere. We passed this area during out canal trip by boat. Though it was cloudy, we still enjoyed our walk in this area. The atmosphere is perfect, the houses, the street, the boat and the canal just in place make this area beautiful. Sit at the edge of the canal and enjoy the atmosphere.

Get Lost in Dam Amsterdam.!.. Amsterdam "IS" canals,. So if you don't do a canal trip then you have not done Amsterdam.This is sure a nice place, not sleezy at all, liedesplien is smart too.A walk up the Dam is a Damn walk, but "a must be done" for shopaholics.A take your time and enjoy city, with a coffee shop, cake shop, cigar shop, and much more than that too......... A very cutured, steeped in history and vibrant place to be.Deserves a life time achievement award, if you put this on your top list.!.

Home of excellent pancakes. A mustbtrybis the pancake bakery or pancake factory in this area. I recommend the nutella and banana pancake or any of the omelettes. Be warned ... 1 is big enough for 2 males with decent appetites tonshare
Nice to see. We walked there during the day and night, just beautiful!
an interesting street. we strolled along prinsengracht street during the day and night. Many interesting boats, some of them with gardens and flowers, the church, pancake factory, anna frank's house.
Beautiful area. Wester Bar has a great seating area right across from Anne Frank House/museum
Walking along the Prinsengracht. I liked walking along all the 'grachts' by the canals, while I was in Amsterdam. Fun.
Walk, Walk, Walk. Lovely stretch of Canal that takes you through all different areas of the city. Just walk and enjoy.
Stroll and enjoy!. Private little gardens on the street with pots filled with flowers amid parked bikes and scooters.
Stunning. Prinsengracht is absolutely beautiful to walk along. Just watch out for the bike riders!
A wonderful stroll to the Anne Frank Museum.. Charming street to soak in a bit of life in Amsterdam.

A piece of history preserved. Previously I stayed in a hotel along the Prinsengracht and was struck by the beauty of the area. Although I was not lucky enough to find a hotel available in this area I found myself going back there just to enjoy the history and beauty of the place.
Fab!. This is a nice stretch of water where you can wander around as much as you like & take in as many sights & sounds as possible.

Gorgeous!. As well as the main street that runs along the Prinsengracht, we spent our time weaving through the little streets that cross this canal and intersect with it, mainly in the Joordan area. It's all beautiful in summer.

A pretty walk shows you the old and new.. Seeing real Amsterdam inhabitants going to work, taking their children to school, all on foot or by bicycle. Narrow old Dutch buildings and houseboats line the canal.

Lovely!!. Exploring canals by bike or boat..either way - amazing experience!!

Great stop for sandwiches and tea. Read about this place in a guide book, but didn't necessarily seek it out. We stumbled onto it as we were walking about. It was a chilly day and it looked welcoming. Reasonably priced sandwiches, warm tea and friendly staff. We didn't try the apple pie, but it looked amazing. Huge slices at least 6" deep.
Walk along the canal. We walked almost the full length of this canal and enjoyed every step. Very relaxed and, if you go off piste, some varied areas.
nice to walk. one of the central canal, nice to walk. You can visit some museum or take a seat in one of numerous cafe with water view

Most beatifull canal in Amsterdam. It's my opinion, don't shoot me. Like the smaller canal buildings, of course the Anne Frank House and the Wester Church. When I walk along the canal I prefere this one.

Great Area to Walk. Of course we visited Anne Frank's house. It was a very moving museum visit. Prisengracht is a lovely area and we recommend just walking around exploring the connecting streets and canals. There are shops, galleries and many good restaurants to visit.

Great Area to Walk. Of course we visited Anne Frank's house. It was a very moving museum visit. Prisengracht is a lovely area and we recommend just walking around exploring the connecting streets and canals. There are shops, galleries and many good restaurants to visit.
Pedalo heaven. Rent a canal bike (pedalo) and explore the canals yourself rather than an overpriced boat trip.

Fascinating and unique. Watch Dutch life go by from a bridge and take in houseboats, vintage pleasure boats and working barges while you admire the beautiful buildings along the canals, as bicycles zoom by: well-deserved world heritage recognition and one of the best experiences anywhere

canals. a touch of Amsterdam from the past and a quieter retrest from the hectic sand often very dirty littered streets

Great place to spend the night. Bars, Restaurants and things happening - expensive area to stay - but your in the midst of things to do
Great location with amazing and fantastic atmosphere!. I like all this area and my family also. I could recommend.

before you go aboard, for there a very tiny toilet at the back of most boats with a very low ceiling. Tall men have to use it as a urinoir, on their knees...

Grace And Lovely Architecture Resonate Here. Like all Amsterdam's lovely canals, the Prinsengracht is quiet and graceful, and is a showcase for what is amongst the most civilized domestic architecture in the world. The Dutch artfully combine level headed practicality with a sense of down-to-earth style that is on show along this waterway. Walk the canals, or consider renting a bike to see the city - this must be the western world's premier bike city.
Bohemian Atmosphere. In addition to a beautiful canal with house boats the area includes many art galleries and unusual shops selling imported itms.
lovely. the canals in Amsterdam are surprising clean. Very picuresque.

Beautiful. Beautiful architecture and a lovely atmosphere, whether you're strolling around or taking a boat! My parents (in their 50s) are convinced people only go to Amsterdam for partying, but I'm trying to convince them to go as they would love wandering around this beautiful city!
prowling for art. lots of small art oriented shops in the side streets west of the canal
Prisengracht. Many good restaurants and boutiques close to the Rijkmuseum and the Van Gogh museum. A block from Vongelpark a block away.
Nice views. It was nice to walk about just taking in the views and going to Anne Frank Huis.Visit was in Oct 2010

Wonderful cafes and pancake restaurants. When in Amsterdam it is always important to take time to stroll the canal system and stop in at a cafe to people watch or more importantly watch the city go by on bicycles!
pretty canal street. nice short walk down the canal. Great houses on this street.

You can find all sorts of boutiques, particularly near the busy bridges, but there are also very many quiet spots on some bridges which are lovely for a pause and reflection (literally) on a warm and sunny spring morning! Forget Dam square and Rembrandt Plein this area tops the lot. There is an abundance of lovely little local bars and cafes as well as restaurants around this area. It is great to absorb some local culture and cuisine here and away from all the hustle and bustle of the main streets.
Typical Dutch canal scene.. Just leasurely stroll these canals and regain your senses.

The old and beautiful Prinsengracht. We had the opportunity to stayed in a marvelous house on Prinsengracht, The Posthoorn b@b.So, we went every day along this magnificent canal, looking the old houses, none the same.WORDS CAN'T DESCRIBE THE BEAUTY OF THIS AREA OF AMSTERDAM. THE ONLY ADVICE THAT WE CAN DO IS... COME AND SEE AND LIVE!

Beautiful street in the heart of Amsterdam. We enjoyed walking the canal along Prinsengracht. Nice views homes, shops, and a large church. You'll also find Anne Franks house/museum. We came to a beautiful shop, "Galleria d'Arte Rinascimento" full of old and new Delftware, Royal Delft located on Prinsengracht across from big Church.
something special. We took a boat tour on the canals, very nice to be on the water and to see all those old houses go by.... For me this is nice as we do not have this in Japan, really worth it.

we stayed just 1 block off this canal. We stayed in a vrbo.com apartment rental, but saw a Mercure hotel right on our little residential street. My husband mentioned that it was a Frommer's pick. If we had wanted just a hotel, not a small apartment, that would have been an ideal location. So close to a tram, walk to Leidesplein, grocery store, sandwich shops, a couple of small cafes, a reknown bakery, even a mellow yellow - all within a couple of blocks. It's a wonderful neighborhood to walk in the early morning and evening. Well, anytime of day!
Beautiful Canals. Prinsengracht is one of Amsterdam's several canals. Gracht = canal in Dutch. Anne Frankhuis is along this canal.
Shoes and more shoes. If you love shoes you will find fabulous ones here. Also good eats. Good cheese store there too!
Picturesque and beautiful area. A must visit to stroll or bike around this area with outdoor cafes, shops and wonderful people watching.
Great area to explore. As one meanders through the many delightful neighbourhoods, this main 'artery' leads to an array of eclectic streets. Not to be missed!

Blissful day. Better than meditation or an afternoon at the spa. Wear comfortable shoes, and walk up and down Prinsengracht. Take in the little shops, restos and cafes and the gorgeous graded buildings. It is one of the most delightful streets in Europe. After an hour, I could not help but walking with a smile on my face.
Great canal action. There's loads to do in this area and some good eateries - a good area to hang out in on a lazy sunny afternoon.
The preferred canal. Walk the length of this canal and marvel over the people, places, and the elegant bike riders rolling over the cobblestones. Stop in the middle of the bridges and take it in!

A must if you are at Amsterdam. Autum and Spring are the best season to visit. Take your time and use a guide from the tourist organisation for more info or hire a guide to explain all the historic things or go by boad canal taxi.

Beautiful views on the canal & beautiful mansions. The three canals: the Prinsengracht, the Herengracht and the Kezersgracht are amongst the most lovely sites in Amsterdam. Beautiful, peaceful views on the canal and many beautiful houses and mansions... a very cosy atmosphere.
Very lovely "Euro" feel. A lovely area to stroll and shop. Beautiful restaurant Basserie Vlaming at 193a~ order toffee pie~ you won't be sorry!
Beautiful area for walking. Lovely place to walk, look in shop, and linger in little cafes.
Great canal area. Architecture and great shops make for a great area to walk and enjoy Amsterdam
Central area.. One of the central districts in Amsterdam. The area of the 'nine streets' is full of fab boutiques, bars and great snack food places. Not expensive, and great coffee and pastries.
great walking area. Great walking area with many shops and street cafes to choose from
Amazing. The canals are gorgeous... so much history... the right guidebook will tell you who lived in which canal house, which royalty visited who where, etc!
An enjoyable walk that links interesting areas.. Some grand architecture along this beautiful canal. Well worth a stroll as you visit interesting areas on the way.
Canal walking. Like the other two famous canals this one curves between old buildings, bars, cafes, clubs and restaurants

Prinsengracht - Princes' canal worth several visits. The Prinsengracht - included in what the Dutch call " National Monument" site - is worth several visits in one day. What you see on your canal boat trip, would be totally different from what you will experience, and more, when you go strolling down Prinsengracht - the Princes' canal.Apart from the historic buildings, the different architectural styles and the cobble-stoned width of the road beside the canal that could not be further widened since a few hundred years ago, one gets a glimpse of a certain life-style of the Amsterdamers, for example, as per the following:1) The shops, art galleries, the restaurants, etc. along the "gracht" (= meaning "canal"), also in the various side streets branching off Prinsengracht and the other canals - these establishments are not there just for the tourists, so here you can shop and eat like the locals do (not at tourist prices);2) on Saturday mornings in the Lindengracht (off the Prinsengracht) there is a "mile long", " wet-market" - there you can find stalls selling fresh fruits, veggies, fish, cheeses, breads, etc, including stalls selling arts and crafts, clothings, shoes, etc AND you can buy and taste Dutch herring and other fish delicacies at local (not tourist) prices;3) also on Saturday mornings, near the Lindengracht market is a "farmers' market" selling organic products;4) on Monday mornings (but not in the winter months) at the location of the "farmermers' market" is where you find an arts and crafts, antique and second-hand goods market. Who knows what "gems" you can find there ?Please take note the abovementioned are happenings "in the mornings", which means if you go in the afternoons you are likely to miss the "real thing".Suggestion:Do go in the mornings - to survey the place and visit the markets that the locals go to eat, then have coffee, bagles, and rest by the open-air terraces serving refreshments and drinks.In the afternoon, check out the shops - there are many quaint specialty type shops (most have been there for many, many years) - for example, shops selling nothing but candles, nothing but board games, nothing but cook books, vintage clothes, vintage books, and so on. Also do check out the restaurants where the locals eat ( menus and prices are usually displayed outside).In the evenings, stroll down the lighted canal and pop into one of the "brown cafes" for a drink or night-cap, and see how the locals enjoy themselves.We visit Amsterdam every year and we find the time spent strolling along the Prinsengracht, the Herengracht (=Dukes' canal) and the Keizersgracht (=Emperors' canal) as time well spend at different times of the day, because the scenery and the flow of activity changes all day long. Hot-tip:1) If you plan to come to Amsterdam in the late summer, do search online for the opening times and dates when several of the historical buildings along the canals, which are "still-in-working-order" and classified as "National Monuments", are open for viewing to the public, free of charge. If you can can get into some of these buildings, it will be truly a great "Dutch" experience.2) If you go to Amsterdam in early August, check out on-line for dates of (a) the gay (day-time) parade, (b) Prinsengracht open-air on the water classical music (evening) concert performance - these are both free of charge and an experience that is second to none.
Historical Architecture. The history behind this world class city is represented in the architecture of Prinsengracht - the merchant princes' homes.
Central and lovely. Worth walking down as well as viewing from true boat

A Lovely Walk. The Prinsengracht was located very close to our hotel. We had the pleasure of walking along it on several occasions, as we made our way to other attractions in the city. I would rate this as an excellent way to see some of the true sights and sounds of Amsterdam, away from the hustle and bustle of Dam Square and Centraal Station. The architecture is lovely, and the scenery charming. There is significant bike traffic, and a little vehicle traffic, so mind your little ones if they are along for the walk.

A pleasant walk. A wide canal bilt to keep out the workers in the Jordaan, rather ironic now as this is one of the smartest areas in town. some good restaurants and a very pleasant walk up towards the Western Islands.

The one gracht (canal) you don't want to miss.. The Prinsengracht, or Prince's Canal, is in my opinion the one canal you don't want to miss. A walk along the entire canal is basically the best way to see the history of the city. The Northern stretch especially, where you will find the Westkerk (west church), the Anne Franke Huis, Cafe t'Smalle and Spanger Van Twist, further Up North the Noordkerk (North Church) and cafe Pappeneiland. Look at all the house front tops, or "Gables" to see the classic Amsterdam architecture. Just one of the most wonderful places on the planet.
nice are. Prinsengracht is the picture postcard image that you have of Amsterdam and it is a quiet away from the hustle and bustle

Picturesque, Quiet(er), Lovely Walking. So the Prinsengracht is one of the main canals in Amsterdam, and if you start your walk just west of the Centraal Station it's the fourth canal you come to - on the outside of the "ring" as it were - Singel, Herengracht, Keizersgracht, then Prinsengracht (gracht=canal). You'll walk south away from the station and eventually curve around east - it's a long walk! On the way, enjoy the shops, the cafes, bars and restaurants. You'll pass the outer edge of the Nine Streets shopping district - do some exploring and check out, for example, De Kaaskamer on Runstraat (I think the best cheese shop in Amsterdam.). If you're into the coffeehouse scene, do stop at La Tertulia for a smoke - very friendly, welcoming, pretty and relaxed. If you keep going you'll come to Leidsestraat and can take a short detour south to Leidseplein, or keep on truckin' to Museumbrug and take that to the Rijksmuseum. Tired? Catch the tram or a canal boat to take you back near Centraal Station. One of my favorite walks anywhere.

Strolling through history. A stroll along one of Amsterdam's most famous canals is like walking through history. It takes you to Anne Frank's house, from the cozy Jordaan neighborhood to the river Amstel, running into houseboots, plenty of cafes, boutique shopping nirvana 'De 9 straatjes', galleries, restaurants and bricks and bricks that where stacked during Amsterdam's golden age.

Prisengracht on Ice!. Fabulous time on the frozen canals this weekend. I know it only happens every couple of years, so if you happen to be in Amsterdam when the canals freeze you CANNOT miss out walking or skating on the ice. Look out for the entrepreneurial Dutch and the little ice-cafes that pop up everywhere. And please, please, please, do not stop to take photos of the ice when walking under the bridges! That ice isn't all that solid and it makes the locals nervous! Keep on walking!

Stayed at the Pulitzer Hotel right ON this canal!. Extremely charming long canal--with lots of lovely homes, shops, and historic venues, including the Westerkirk and Anne Frank House. We walked along it nearly to the RIjksmusem and Van Gogh Museum--a long but pleasant walk--and back. The Pulitzer Hotel has a private canal boat for once-a-day tours at 5 p.m., which we didn't do as our time was limited and we did an extensive canal tour a few years ago (AND we were just off a 24-day transatlantic cruise, so water was not our primary objective!)--but being ON this well located canal was a highlight of our 3 post-cruise days in wonderful Amsterdam.
